summary.long: 2 Chronicles is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: Solomon son of David took firm control of his kingdom, for the Lord his God was with him and made him very powerful.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon called together all the leaders of Israel—the generals and captains of the army, the judges, and all the political and clan leaders.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he led the entire assembly to the place of worship in Gibeon, for God’s Tabernacle was located there. (This was the Tabernacle that Moses, the Lord’s servant, had made in the wilderness.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David had already moved the Ark of God from Kiriath-jearim to the tent he had prepared for it in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the bronze altar made by Bezalel son of Uri and grandson of Hur was there at Gibeon in front of the Tabernacle of the Lord. So Solomon and the people gathered in front of it to consult the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There in front of the Tabernacle, Solomon went up to the bronze altar in the Lord’s presence and sacrificed 1,000 burnt offerings on it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That night God appeared to Solomon and said, “What do you want? Ask, and I will give it to you!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon replied to God, “You showed great and faithful love to David, my father, and now you have made me king in his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: O Lord God, please continue to keep your promise to David my father, for you have made me king over a people as numerous as the dust of the earth!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Give me the wisdom and knowledge to lead them properly, for who could possibly govern this great people of yours?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God said to Solomon, “Because your greatest desire is to help your people, and you did not ask for wealth, riches, fame, or even the death of your enemies or a long life, but rather you asked for wisdom and knowledge to properly govern my people—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will certainly give you the wisdom and knowledge you requested. But I will also give you wealth, riches, and fame such as no other king has had before you or will ever have in the future!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Solomon returned to Jerusalem from the Tabernacle at the place of worship in Gibeon, and he reigned over Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon built up a huge force of chariots and horses. He had 1,400 chariots and 12,000 horses. He stationed some of them in the chariot cities and some near him in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king made silver and gold as plentiful in Jerusalem as stone. And valuable cedar timber was as common as the sycamore-fig trees that grow in the foothills of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon’s horses were imported from Egypt and from Cilicia; the king’s traders acquired them from Cilicia at the standard price.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time chariots from Egypt could be purchased for 600 pieces of silver, and horses for 150 pieces of silver. They were then exported to the kings of the Hittites and the kings of Aram.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon decided to build a Temple to honor the name of the Lord, and also a royal palace for himself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He enlisted a force of 70,000 laborers, 80,000 men to quarry stone in the hill country, and 3,600 foremen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Solomon also sent this message to King Hiram at Tyre:
“Send me cedar logs as you did for my father, David, when he was building his palace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am about to build a Temple to honor the name of the Lord my God. It will be a place set apart to burn fragrant incense before him, to display the special sacrificial bread, and to sacrifice burnt offerings each morning and evening, on the Sabbaths, at new moon celebrations, and at the other appointed festivals of the Lord our God. He has commanded Israel to do these things forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This must be a magnificent Temple because our God is greater than all other gods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But who can really build him a worthy home? Not even the highest heavens can contain him! So who am I to consider building a Temple for him, except as a place to burn sacrifices to him?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “So send me a master craftsman who can work with gold, silver, bronze, and iron, as well as with purple, scarlet, and blue cloth. He must be a skilled engraver who can work with the craftsmen of Judah and Jerusalem who were selected by my father, David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Also send me cedar, cypress, and red sandalwood logs from Lebanon, for I know that your men are without equal at cutting timber in Lebanon. I will send my men to help them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: An immense amount of timber will be needed, for the Temple I am going to build will be very large and magnificent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In payment for your woodcutters, I will send 100,000 bushels of crushed wheat, 100,000 bushels of barley, 110,000 gallons of wine, and 110,000 gallons of olive oil.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
King Hiram sent this letter of reply to Solomon:
“It is because the Lord loves his people that he has made you their king!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Praise the Lord, the God of Israel, who made the heavens and the earth! He has given King David a wise son, gifted with skill and understanding, who will build a Temple for the Lord and a royal palace for himself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I am sending you a master craftsman named Huram-abi, who is extremely talented.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His mother is from the tribe of Dan in Israel, and his father is from Tyre. He is skillful at making things from gold, silver, bronze, and iron, and he also works with stone and wood. He can work with purple, blue, and scarlet cloth and fine linen. He is also an engraver and can follow any design given to him. He will work with your craftsmen and those appointed by my lord David, your father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Send along the wheat, barley, olive oil, and wine that my lord has mentioned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We will cut whatever timber you need from the Lebanon mountains and will float the logs in rafts down the coast of the Mediterranean Sea to Joppa. From there you can transport the logs up to Jerusalem.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon took a census of all foreigners in the land of Israel, like the census his father had taken, and he counted 153,600.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He assigned 70,000 of them as common laborers, 80,000 as quarry workers in the hill country, and 3,600 as foremen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Solomon began to build the Temple of the Lord in Jerusalem on Mount Moriah, where the Lord had appeared to David, his father. The Temple was built on the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite, the site that David had selected.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The construction began in midspring, during the fourth year of Solomon’s reign.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the dimensions Solomon used for the foundation of the Temple of God (using the old standard of measurement). It was 90 feet long and 30 feet wide.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The entry room at the front of the Temple was 30 feet wide, running across the entire width of the Temple, and 30 feet high. He overlaid the inside with pure gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He paneled the main room of the Temple with cypress wood, overlaid it with fine gold, and decorated it with carvings of palm trees and chains.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He decorated the walls of the Temple with beautiful jewels and with gold from the land of Parvaim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He overlaid the beams, thresholds, walls, and doors throughout the Temple with gold, and he carved figures of cherubim on the walls.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made the Most Holy Place 30 feet wide, corresponding to the width of the Temple, and 30 feet deep. He overlaid its interior with 23 tons of fine gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The gold nails that were used weighed 20 ounces each. He also overlaid the walls of the upper rooms with gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made two figures shaped like cherubim, overlaid them with gold, and placed them in the Most Holy Place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The total wingspan of the two cherubim standing side by side was 30 feet. One wing of the first figure was 7 1⁄2 feet long, and it touched the Temple wall. The other wing, also 7 1⁄2 feet long, touched one of the wings of the second figure.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the same way, the second figure had one wing 7 1⁄2 feet long that touched the opposite wall. The other wing, also 7 1⁄2 feet long, touched the wing of the first figure.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the wingspan of the two cherubim side by side was 30 feet. They stood on their feet and faced out toward the main room of the Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Across the entrance of the Most Holy Place he hung a curtain made of fine linen, decorated with blue, purple, and scarlet thread and embroidered with figures of cherubim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the front of the Temple, he made two pillars that were 27 feet tall, each topped by a capital extending upward another 7 1⁄2 feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made a network of interwoven chains and used them to decorate the tops of the pillars. He also made 100 decorative pomegranates and attached them to the chains.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he set up the two pillars at the entrance of the Temple, one to the south of the entrance and the other to the north. He named the one on the south Jakin, and the one on the north Boaz.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon also made a bronze altar 30 feet long, 30 feet wide, and 15 feet high.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he cast a great round basin, 15 feet across from rim to rim, called the Sea. It was 7 1⁄2 feet deep and about 45 feet in circumference.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It was encircled just below its rim by two rows of figures that resembled oxen. There were about six oxen per foot all the way around, and they were cast as part of the basin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Sea was placed on a base of twelve bronze oxen, all facing outward. Three faced north, three faced west, three faced south, and three faced east, and the Sea rested on them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The walls of the Sea were about three inches thick, and its rim flared out like a cup and resembled a water lily blossom. It could hold about 16,500 gallons of water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also made ten smaller basins for washing the utensils for the burnt offerings. He set five on the south side and five on the north. But the priests washed themselves in the Sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He then cast ten gold lampstands according to the specifications that had been given, and he put them in the Temple. Five were placed against the south wall, and five were placed against the north wall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also built ten tables and placed them in the Temple, five along the south wall and five along the north wall. Then he molded 100 gold basins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He then built a courtyard for the priests, and also the large outer courtyard. He made doors for the courtyard entrances and overlaid them with bronze.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The great bronze basin called the Sea was placed near the southeast corner of the Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Huram-abi also made the necessary washbasins, shovels, and bowls.
So at last Huram-abi completed everything King Solomon had assigned him to make for the Temple of God:
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text: the 400 pomegranates that hung from the chains on the capitals (two rows of pomegranates for each of the chain networks that decorated the capitals on top of the pillars);
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the water carts holding the basins;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the Sea and the twelve oxen under it;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
the ash buckets, the shovels, the meat hooks, and all the related articles.
Huram-abi made all these things of burnished bronze for the Temple of the Lord, just as King Solomon had directed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king had them cast in clay molds in the Jordan Valley between Succoth and Zarethan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon used such great quantities of bronze that its weight could not be determined.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text: the lampstands and their lamps of solid gold, to burn in front of the Most Holy Place as prescribed;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the flower decorations, lamps, and tongs—all of the purest gold;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
the lamp snuffers, bowls, ladles, and incense burners—all of solid gold;
the doors for the entrances to the Most Holy Place and the main room of the Temple, overlaid with gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Solomon finished all his work on the Temple of the Lord. Then he brought all the gifts his father, David, had dedicated—the silver, the gold, and the various articles—and he stored them in the treasuries of the Temple of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon then summoned to Jerusalem the elders of Israel and all the heads of tribes—the leaders of the ancestral families of Israel. They were to bring the Ark of the Lord’s Covenant to the Temple from its location in the City of David, also known as Zion.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So all the men of Israel assembled before the king at the annual Festival of Shelters, which is held in early autumn.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all the elders of Israel arrived, the Levites picked up the Ark.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests and Levites brought up the Ark along with the special tent and all the sacred items that had been in it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There, before the Ark, King Solomon and the entire community of Israel sacrificed so many sheep, goats, and cattle that no one could keep count!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the priests carried the Ark of the Lord’s Covenant into the inner sanctuary of the Temple—the Most Holy Place—and placed it beneath the wings of the cherubim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The cherubim spread their wings over the Ark, forming a canopy over the Ark and its carrying poles.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These poles were so long that their ends could be seen from the Holy Place, which is in front of the Most Holy Place, but not from the outside. They are still there to this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nothing was in the Ark except the two stone tablets that Moses had placed in it at Mount Sinai, where the Lord made a covenant with the people of Israel when they left Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the priests left the Holy Place. All the priests who were present had purified themselves, whether or not they were on duty that day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Levites who were musicians—Asaph, Heman, Jeduthun, and all their sons and brothers—were dressed in fine linen robes and stood at the east side of the altar playing cymbals, lyres, and harps. They were joined by 120 priests who were playing trumpets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The trumpeters and singers performed together in unison to praise and give thanks to the Lord. Accompanied by trumpets, cymbals, and other instruments, they raised their voices and praised the Lord with these words:
“He is good!
    His faithful love endures forever!”
At that moment a thick cloud filled the Temple of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests could not continue their service because of the cloud, for the glorious presence of the Lord filled the Temple of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Solomon prayed, “O Lord, you have said that you would live in a thick cloud of darkness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now I have built a glorious Temple for you, a place where you can live forever!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king turned around to the entire community of Israel standing before him and gave this blessing:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Praise the Lord, the God of Israel, who has kept the promise he made to my father, David. For he told my father,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘From the day I brought my people out of the land of Egypt, I have never chosen a city among any of the tribes of Israel as the place where a Temple should be built to honor my name. Nor have I chosen a king to lead my people Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now I have chosen Jerusalem as the place for my name to be honored, and I have chosen David to be king over my people Israel.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Solomon said, “My father, David, wanted to build this Temple to honor the name of the Lord, the God of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord told him, ‘You wanted to build the Temple to honor my name. Your intention is good,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but you are not the one to do it. One of your own sons will build the Temple to honor me.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “And now the Lord has fulfilled the promise he made, for I have become king in my father’s place, and now I sit on the throne of Israel, just as the Lord promised. I have built this Temple to honor the name of the Lord, the God of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There I have placed the Ark, which contains the covenant that the Lord made with the people of Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Solomon stood before the altar of the Lord in front of the entire community of Israel, and he lifted his hands in prayer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Solomon had made a bronze platform 7 1⁄2 feet long, 7 1⁄2 feet wide, and 4 1⁄2 feet high and had placed it at the center of the Temple’s outer courtyard. He stood on the platform, and then he knelt in front of the entire community of Israel and lifted his hands toward heaven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He prayed,
“O Lord, God of Israel, there is no God like you in all of heaven and earth. You keep your covenant and show unfailing love to all who walk before you in wholehearted devotion.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You have kept your promise to your servant David, my father. You made that promise with your own mouth, and with your own hands you have fulfilled it today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “And now, O Lord, God of Israel, carry out the additional promise you made to your servant David, my father. For you said to him, ‘If your descendants guard their behavior and faithfully follow my Law as you have done, one of them will always sit on the throne of Israel.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, O Lord, God of Israel, fulfill this promise to your servant David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But will God really live on earth among people? Why, even the highest heavens cannot contain you. How much less this Temple I have built!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nevertheless, listen to my prayer and my plea, O Lord my God. Hear the cry and the prayer that your servant is making to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May you watch over this Temple day and night, this place where you have said you would put your name. May you always hear the prayers I make toward this place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May you hear the humble and earnest requests from me and your people Israel when we pray toward this place. Yes, hear us from heaven where you live, and when you hear, forgive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If someone wrongs another person and is required to take an oath of innocence in front of your altar at this Temple,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then hear from heaven and judge between your servants—the accuser and the accused. Pay back the guilty as they deserve. Acquit the innocent because of their innocence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If your people Israel are defeated by their enemies because they have sinned against you, and if they turn back and acknowledge your name and pray to you here in this Temple,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then hear from heaven and forgive the sin of your people Israel and return them to this land you gave to them and to their ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If the skies are shut up and there is no rain because your people have sinned against you, and if they pray toward this Temple and acknowledge your name and turn from their sins because you have punished them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then hear from heaven and forgive the sins of your servants, your people Israel. Teach them to follow the right path, and send rain on your land that you have given to your people as their special possession.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If there is a famine in the land or a plague or crop disease or attacks of locusts or caterpillars, or if your people’s enemies are in the land besieging their towns—whatever disaster or disease there is—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and if your people Israel pray about their troubles or sorrow, raising their hands toward this Temple,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then hear from heaven where you live, and forgive. Give your people what their actions deserve, for you alone know each human heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they will fear you and walk in your ways as long as they live in the land you gave to our ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “In the future, foreigners who do not belong to your people Israel will hear of you. They will come from distant lands when they hear of your great name and your strong hand and your powerful arm. And when they pray toward this Temple,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then hear from heaven where you live, and grant what they ask of you. In this way, all the people of the earth will come to know and fear you, just as your own people Israel do. They, too, will know that this Temple I have built honors your name.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If your people go out where you send them to fight their enemies, and if they pray to you by turning toward this city you have chosen and toward this Temple I have built to honor your name,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then hear their prayers from heaven and uphold their cause.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If they sin against you—and who has never sinned?—you might become angry with them and let their enemies conquer them and take them captive to a foreign land far away or near.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But in that land of exile, they might turn to you in repentance and pray, ‘We have sinned, done evil, and acted wickedly.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If they turn to you with their whole heart and soul in the land of their captivity and pray toward the land you gave to their ancestors—toward this city you have chosen, and toward this Temple I have built to honor your name—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then hear their prayers and their petitions from heaven where you live, and uphold their cause. Forgive your people who have sinned against you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “O my God, may your eyes be open and your ears attentive to all the prayers made to you in this place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“And now arise, O Lord God, and enter your resting place,
    along with the Ark, the symbol of your power.
May your priests, O Lord God, be clothed with salvation;
    may your loyal servants rejoice in your goodness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
O Lord God, do not reject the king you have anointed.
    Remember your unfailing love for your servant David.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Solomon finished praying, fire flashed down from heaven and burned up the burnt offerings and sacrifices, and the glorious presence of the Lord filled the Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests could not enter the Temple of the Lord because the glorious presence of the Lord filled it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When all the people of Israel saw the fire coming down and the glorious presence of the Lord filling the Temple, they fell face down on the ground and worshiped and praised the Lord, saying,
“He is good!
    His faithful love endures forever!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king and all the people offered sacrifices to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon offered a sacrifice of 22,000 cattle and 120,000 sheep and goats. And so the king and all the people dedicated the Temple of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests took their assigned positions, and so did the Levites who were singing, “His faithful love endures forever!” They accompanied the singing with music from the instruments King David had made for praising the Lord. Across from the Levites, the priests blew the trumpets, while all Israel stood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon then consecrated the central area of the courtyard in front of the Lord’s Temple. He offered burnt offerings and the fat of peace offerings there, because the bronze altar he had built could not hold all the burnt offerings, grain offerings, and sacrificial fat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the next seven days Solomon and all Israel celebrated the Festival of Shelters. A large congregation had gathered from as far away as Lebo-hamath in the north and the Brook of Egypt in the south.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the eighth day they had a closing ceremony, for they had celebrated the dedication of the altar for seven days and the Festival of Shelters for seven days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then at the end of the celebration, Solomon sent the people home. They were all joyful and glad because the Lord had been so good to David and to Solomon and to his people Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Solomon finished the Temple of the Lord, as well as the royal palace. He completed everything he had planned to do in the construction of the Temple and the palace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then one night the Lord appeared to Solomon and said,
“I have heard your prayer and have chosen this Temple as the place for making sacrifices.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At times I might shut up the heavens so that no rain falls, or command grasshoppers to devour your crops, or send plagues among you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then if my people who are called by my name will humble themselves and pray and seek my face and turn from their wicked ways, I will hear from heaven and will forgive their sins and restore their land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My eyes will be open and my ears attentive to every prayer made in this place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For I have chosen this Temple and set it apart to be holy—a place where my name will be honored forever. I will always watch over it, for it is dear to my heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “As for you, if you faithfully follow me as David your father did, obeying all my commands, decrees, and regulations,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then I will establish the throne of your dynasty. For I made this covenant with your father, David, when I said, ‘One of your descendants will always rule over Israel.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But if you or your descendants abandon me and disobey the decrees and commands I have given you, and if you serve and worship other gods,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then I will uproot the people from this land that I have given them. I will reject this Temple that I have made holy to honor my name. I will make it an object of mockery and ridicule among the nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And though this Temple is impressive now, all who pass by will be appalled. They will ask, ‘Why did the Lord do such terrible things to this land and to this Temple?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “And the answer will be, ‘Because his people abandoned the Lord, the God of their ancestors, who brought them out of Egypt, and they worshiped other gods instead and bowed down to them. That is why he has brought all these disasters on them.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It took Solomon twenty years to build the Lord’s Temple and his own royal palace. At the end of that time,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon turned his attention to rebuilding the towns that King Hiram had given him, and he settled Israelites in them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon also fought against the town of Hamath-zobah and conquered it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He rebuilt Tadmor in the wilderness and built towns in the region of Hamath as supply centers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He fortified the towns of Upper Beth-horon and Lower Beth-horon, rebuilding their walls and installing barred gates.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also rebuilt Baalath and other supply centers and constructed towns where his chariots and horses could be stationed. He built everything he desired in Jerusalem and Lebanon and throughout his entire realm.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were still some people living in the land who were not Israelites, including the Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were descendants of the nations whom the people of Israel had not destroyed. So Solomon conscripted them for his labor force, and they serve as forced laborers to this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Solomon did not conscript any of the Israelites for his labor force. Instead, he assigned them to serve as fighting men, officers in his army, commanders of his chariots, and charioteers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon appointed 250 of them to supervise the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon moved his wife, Pharaoh’s daughter, from the City of David to the new palace he had built for her. He said, “My wife must not live in King David’s palace, for the Ark of the Lord has been there, and it is holy ground.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Solomon presented burnt offerings to the Lord on the altar he had built for him in front of the entry room of the Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He offered the sacrifices for the Sabbaths, the new moon festivals, and the three annual festivals—the Passover celebration, the Festival of Harvest, and the Festival of Shelters—as Moses had commanded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In assigning the priests to their duties, Solomon followed the regulations of his father, David. He also assigned the Levites to lead the people in praise and to assist the priests in their daily duties. And he assigned the gatekeepers to their gates by their divisions, following the commands of David, the man of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon did not deviate in any way from David’s commands concerning the priests and Levites and the treasuries.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Solomon made sure that all the work related to building the Temple of the Lord was carried out, from the day its foundation was laid to the day of its completion.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later Solomon went to Ezion-geber and Elath, ports along the shore of the Red Sea in the land of Edom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hiram sent him ships commanded by his own officers and manned by experienced crews of sailors. These ships sailed to Ophir with Solomon’s men and brought back to Solomon almost seventeen tons of gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the queen of Sheba heard of Solomon’s fame, she came to Jerusalem to test him with hard questions. She arrived with a large group of attendants and a great caravan of camels loaded with spices, large quantities of gold, and precious jewels. When she met with Solomon, she talked with him about everything she had on her mind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon had answers for all her questions; nothing was too hard for him to explain to her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the queen of Sheba realized how wise Solomon was, and when she saw the palace he had built,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: she was overwhelmed. She was also amazed at the food on his tables, the organization of his officials and their splendid clothing, the cup-bearers and their robes, and the burnt offerings Solomon made at the Temple of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She exclaimed to the king, “Everything I heard in my country about your achievements and wisdom is true!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I didn’t believe what was said until I arrived here and saw it with my own eyes. In fact, I had not heard the half of your great wisdom! It is far beyond what I was told.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: How happy your people must be! What a privilege for your officials to stand here day after day, listening to your wisdom!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Praise the Lord your God, who delights in you and has placed you on the throne as king to rule for him. Because God loves Israel and desires this kingdom to last forever, he has made you king over them so you can rule with justice and righteousness.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then she gave the king a gift of 9,000 pounds of gold, great quantities of spices, and precious jewels. Never before had there been spices as fine as those the queen of Sheba gave to King Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (In addition, the crews of Hiram and Solomon brought gold from Ophir, and they also brought red sandalwood and precious jewels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king used the sandalwood to make steps for the Temple of the Lord and the royal palace, and to construct lyres and harps for the musicians. Never before had such beautiful things been seen in Judah.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon gave the queen of Sheba whatever she asked for—gifts of greater value than the gifts she had given him. Then she and all her attendants returned to their own land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each year Solomon received about 25 tons of gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This did not include the additional revenue he received from merchants and traders. All the kings of Arabia and the governors of the provinces also brought gold and silver to Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon made 200 large shields of hammered gold, each weighing more than 15 pounds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also made 300 smaller shields of hammered gold, each weighing more than 7 1⁄2 pounds. The king placed these shields in the Palace of the Forest of Lebanon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king made a huge throne, decorated with ivory and overlaid with pure gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The throne had six steps, with a footstool of gold. There were armrests on both sides of the seat, and the figure of a lion stood on each side of the throne.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were also twelve other lions, one standing on each end of the six steps. No other throne in all the world could be compared with it!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All of King Solomon’s drinking cups were solid gold, as were all the utensils in the Palace of the Forest of Lebanon. They were not made of silver, for silver was considered worthless in Solomon’s day!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king had a fleet of trading ships of Tarshish manned by the sailors sent by Hiram. Once every three years the ships returned, loaded with gold, silver, ivory, apes, and peacocks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So King Solomon became richer and wiser than any other king on earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Kings from every nation came to consult him and to hear the wisdom God had given him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Year after year everyone who visited brought him gifts of silver and gold, clothing, weapons, spices, horses, and mules.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon had 4,000 stalls for his horses and chariots, and he had 12,000 horses. He stationed some of them in the chariot cities, and some near him in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He ruled over all the kings from the Euphrates River in the north to the land of the Philistines and the border of Egypt in the south.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king made silver as plentiful in Jerusalem as stone. And valuable cedar timber was as common as the sycamore-fig trees that grow in the foothills of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon’s horses were imported from Egypt and many other countries.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of the events of Solomon’s reign, from beginning to end, are recorded in The Record of Nathan the Prophet, and The Prophecy of Ahijah from Shiloh, and also in The Visions of Iddo the Seer, concerning Jeroboam son of Nebat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon ruled in Jerusalem over all Israel for forty years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he died, he was buried in the City of David, named for his father. Then his son Rehoboam became the next king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rehoboam went to Shechem, where all Israel had gathered to make him king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jeroboam son of Nebat heard of this, he returned from Egypt, for he had fled to Egypt to escape from King Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The leaders of Israel summoned him, and Jeroboam and all Israel went to speak with Rehoboam.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Your father was a hard master,” they said. “Lighten the harsh labor demands and heavy taxes that your father imposed on us. Then we will be your loyal subjects.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rehoboam replied, “Come back in three days for my answer.” So the people went away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King Rehoboam discussed the matter with the older men who had counseled his father, Solomon. “What is your advice?” he asked. “How should I answer these people?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The older counselors replied, “If you are good to these people and do your best to please them and give them a favorable answer, they will always be your loyal subjects.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Rehoboam rejected the advice of the older men and instead asked the opinion of the young men who had grown up with him and were now his advisers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “What is your advice?” he asked them. “How should I answer these people who want me to lighten the burdens imposed by my father?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The young men replied, “This is what you should tell those complainers who want a lighter burden: ‘My little finger is thicker than my father’s waist!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yes, my father laid heavy burdens on you, but I’m going to make them even heavier! My father beat you with whips, but I will beat you with scorpions!’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Three days later Jeroboam and all the people returned to hear Rehoboam’s decision, just as the king had ordered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Rehoboam spoke harshly to them, for he rejected the advice of the older counselors
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and followed the counsel of his younger advisers. He told the people, “My father laid heavy burdens on you, but I’m going to make them even heavier! My father beat you with whips, but I will beat you with scorpions!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king paid no attention to the people. This turn of events was the will of God, for it fulfilled the Lord’s message to Jeroboam son of Nebat through the prophet Ahijah from Shiloh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When all Israel realized that the king had refused to listen to them, they responded,
“Down with the dynasty of David!
    We have no interest in the son of Jesse.
Back to your homes, O Israel!
    Look out for your own house, O David!”
So all the people of Israel returned home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Rehoboam continued to rule over the Israelites who lived in the towns of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Rehoboam sent Adoniram, who was in charge of forced labor, to restore order, but the people of Israel stoned him to death. When this news reached King Rehoboam, he quickly jumped into his chariot and fled to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And to this day the northern tribes of Israel have refused to be ruled by a descendant of David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Rehoboam arrived at Jerusalem, he mobilized the men of Judah and Benjamin—180,000 select troops—to fight against Israel and to restore the kingdom to himself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord said to Shemaiah, the man of God,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Say to Rehoboam son of Solomon, king of Judah, and to all the Israelites in Judah and Benjamin:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘This is what the Lord says: Do not fight against your relatives. Go back home, for what has happened is my doing!’” So they obeyed the message of the Lord and did not fight against Jeroboam.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rehoboam remained in Jerusalem and fortified various towns for the defense of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He built up Bethlehem, Etam, Tekoa,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Beth-zur, Soco, Adullam,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Gath, Mareshah, Ziph,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Adoraim, Lachish, Azekah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zorah, Aijalon, and Hebron. These became the fortified towns of Judah and Benjamin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rehoboam strengthened their defenses and stationed commanders in them, and he stored supplies of food, olive oil, and wine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also put shields and spears in these towns as a further safety measure. So only Judah and Benjamin remained under his control.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But all the priests and Levites living among the northern tribes of Israel sided with Rehoboam.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Levites even abandoned their pasturelands and property and moved to Judah and Jerusalem, because Jeroboam and his sons would not allow them to serve the Lord as priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeroboam appointed his own priests to serve at the pagan shrines, where they worshiped the goat and calf idols he had made.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From all the tribes of Israel, those who sincerely wanted to worship the Lord, the God of Israel, followed the Levites to Jerusalem, where they could offer sacrifices to the Lord, the God of their ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This strengthened the kingdom of Judah, and for three years they supported Rehoboam son of Solomon, for during those years they faithfully followed in the footsteps of David and Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rehoboam married his cousin Mahalath, the daughter of David’s son Jerimoth and of Abihail, the daughter of Eliab son of Jesse.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Mahalath had three sons—Jeush, Shemariah, and Zaham.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later Rehoboam married another cousin, Maacah, the granddaughter of Absalom. Maacah gave birth to Abijah, Attai, Ziza, and Shelomith.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rehoboam loved Maacah more than any of his other wives and concubines. In all, he had eighteen wives and sixty concubines, and they gave birth to twenty-eight sons and sixty daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rehoboam appointed Maacah’s son Abijah as leader among the princes, making it clear that he would be the next king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rehoboam also wisely gave responsibilities to his other sons and stationed some of them in the fortified towns throughout the land of Judah and Benjamin. He provided them with generous provisions, and he found many wives for them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when Rehoboam was firmly established and strong, he abandoned the Law of the Lord, and all Israel followed him in this sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because they were unfaithful to the Lord, King Shishak of Egypt came up and attacked Jerusalem in the fifth year of King Rehoboam’s reign.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He came with 1,200 chariots, 60,000 horses, and a countless army of foot soldiers, including Libyans, Sukkites, and Ethiopians.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shishak conquered Judah’s fortified towns and then advanced to attack Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The prophet Shemaiah then met with Rehoboam and Judah’s leaders, who had all fled to Jerusalem because of Shishak. Shemaiah told them, “This is what the Lord says: You have abandoned me, so I am abandoning you to Shishak.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the leaders of Israel and the king humbled themselves and said, “The Lord is right in doing this to us!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Lord saw their change of heart, he gave this message to Shemaiah: “Since the people have humbled themselves, I will not completely destroy them and will soon give them some relief. I will not use Shishak to pour out my anger on Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But they will become his subjects, so they will know the difference between serving me and serving earthly rulers.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So King Shishak of Egypt came up and attacked Jerusalem. He ransacked the treasuries of the Lord’s Temple and the royal palace; he stole everything, including all the gold shields Solomon had made.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Rehoboam later replaced them with bronze shields as substitutes, and he entrusted them to the care of the commanders of the guard who protected the entrance to the royal palace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whenever the king went to the Temple of the Lord, the guards would also take the shields and then return them to the guardroom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because Rehoboam humbled himself, the Lord’s anger was turned away, and he did not destroy him completely. There were still some good things in the land of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Rehoboam firmly established himself in Jerusalem and continued to rule. He was forty-one years old when he became king, and he reigned seventeen years in Jerusalem, the city the Lord had chosen from among all the tribes of Israel as the place to honor his name. Rehoboam’s mother was Naamah, a woman from Ammon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he was an evil king, for he did not seek the Lord with all his heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of the events of Rehoboam’s reign, from beginning to end, are recorded in The Record of Shemaiah the Prophet and The Record of Iddo the Seer, which are part of the genealogical record. Rehoboam and Jeroboam were continually at war with each other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Rehoboam died, he was buried in the City of David. Then his son Abijah became the next king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abijah began to rule over Judah in the eighteenth year of Jeroboam’s reign in Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He reigned in Jerusalem three years. His mother was Maacah, the daughter of Uriel from Gibeah.
Then war broke out between Abijah and Jeroboam.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Judah, led by King Abijah, fielded 400,000 select warriors, while Jeroboam mustered 800,000 select troops from Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the army of Judah arrived in the hill country of Ephraim, Abijah stood on Mount Zemaraim and shouted to Jeroboam and all Israel: “Listen to me!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t you realize that the Lord, the God of Israel, made a lasting covenant with David, giving him and his descendants the throne of Israel forever?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yet Jeroboam son of Nebat, a mere servant of David’s son Solomon, rebelled against his master.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then a whole gang of scoundrels joined him, defying Solomon’s son Rehoboam when he was young and inexperienced and could not stand up to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do you really think you can stand against the kingdom of the Lord that is led by the descendants of David? You may have a vast army, and you have those gold calves that Jeroboam made as your gods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But you have chased away the priests of the Lord (the descendants of Aaron) and the Levites, and you have appointed your own priests, just like the pagan nations. You let anyone become a priest these days! Whoever comes to be dedicated with a young bull and seven rams can become a priest of these so-called gods of yours!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But as for us, the Lord is our God, and we have not abandoned him. Only the descendants of Aaron serve the Lord as priests, and the Levites alone may help them in their work.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They present burnt offerings and fragrant incense to the Lord every morning and evening. They place the Bread of the Presence on the holy table, and they light the gold lampstand every evening. We are following the instructions of the Lord our God, but you have abandoned him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So you see, God is with us. He is our leader. His priests blow their trumpets and lead us into battle against you. O people of Israel, do not fight against the Lord, the God of your ancestors, for you will not succeed!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, Jeroboam had secretly sent part of his army around behind the men of Judah to ambush them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Judah realized that they were being attacked from the front and the rear, they cried out to the Lord for help. Then the priests blew the trumpets,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the men of Judah began to shout. At the sound of their battle cry, God defeated Jeroboam and all Israel and routed them before Abijah and the army of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelite army fled from Judah, and God handed them over to Judah in defeat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abijah and his army inflicted heavy losses on them; 500,000 of Israel’s select troops were killed that day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Judah defeated Israel on that occasion because they trusted in the Lord, the God of their ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abijah and his army pursued Jeroboam’s troops and captured some of his towns, including Bethel, Jeshanah, and Ephron, along with their surrounding villages.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jeroboam of Israel never regained his power during Abijah’s lifetime, and finally the Lord struck him down and he died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, Abijah of Judah grew more and more powerful. He married fourteen wives and had twenty-two sons and sixteen daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of the events of Abijah’s reign, including his words and deeds, are recorded in The Commentary of Iddo the Prophet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Abijah died, he was buried in the City of David. Then his son Asa became the next king. There was peace in the land for ten years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Asa did what was pleasing and good in the sight of the Lord his God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He removed the foreign altars and the pagan shrines. He smashed the sacred pillars and cut down the Asherah poles.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He commanded the people of Judah to seek the Lord, the God of their ancestors, and to obey his law and his commands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Asa also removed the pagan shrines, as well as the incense altars from every one of Judah’s towns. So Asa’s kingdom enjoyed a period of peace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During those peaceful years, he was able to build up the fortified towns throughout Judah. No one tried to make war against him at this time, for the Lord was giving him rest from his enemies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Asa told the people of Judah, “Let us build towns and fortify them with walls, towers, gates, and bars. The land is still ours because we sought the Lord our God, and he has given us peace on every side.” So they went ahead with these projects and brought them to completion.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Asa had an army of 300,000 warriors from the tribe of Judah, armed with large shields and spears. He also had an army of 280,000 warriors from the tribe of Benjamin, armed with small shields and bows. Both armies were composed of well-trained fighting men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Once an Ethiopian named Zerah attacked Judah with an army of 1,000,000 men and 300 chariots. They advanced to the town of Mareshah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: so Asa deployed his armies for battle in the valley north of Mareshah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Asa cried out to the Lord his God, “O Lord, no one but you can help the powerless against the mighty! Help us, O Lord our God, for we trust in you alone. It is in your name that we have come against this vast horde. O Lord, you are our God; do not let mere men prevail against you!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord defeated the Ethiopians in the presence of Asa and the army of Judah, and the enemy fled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Asa and his army pursued them as far as Gerar, and so many Ethiopians fell that they were unable to rally. They were destroyed by the Lord and his army, and the army of Judah carried off a vast amount of plunder.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While they were at Gerar, they attacked all the towns in that area, and terror from the Lord came upon the people there. As a result, a vast amount of plunder was taken from these towns, too.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They also attacked the camps of herdsmen and captured many sheep, goats, and camels before finally returning to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Spirit of God came upon Azariah son of Oded,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and he went out to meet King Asa as he was returning from the battle. “Listen to me, Asa!” he shouted. “Listen, all you people of Judah and Benjamin! The Lord will stay with you as long as you stay with him! Whenever you seek him, you will find him. But if you abandon him, he will abandon you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For a long time Israel was without the true God, without a priest to teach them, and without the Law to instruct them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But whenever they were in trouble and turned to the Lord, the God of Israel, and sought him out, they found him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “During those dark times, it was not safe to travel. Problems troubled the people of every land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nation fought against nation, and city against city, for God was troubling them with every kind of problem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But as for you, be strong and courageous, for your work will be rewarded.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Asa heard this message from Azariah the prophet, he took courage and removed all the detestable idols from the land of Judah and Benjamin and in the towns he had captured in the hill country of Ephraim. And he repaired the altar of the Lord, which stood in front of the entry room of the Lord’s Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Asa called together all the people of Judah and Benjamin, along with the people of Ephraim, Manasseh, and Simeon who had settled among them. For many from Israel had moved to Judah during Asa’s reign when they saw that the Lord his God was with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people gathered at Jerusalem in late spring, during the fifteenth year of Asa’s reign.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On that day they sacrificed to the Lord 700 cattle and 7,000 sheep and goats from the plunder they had taken in the battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they entered into a covenant to seek the Lord, the God of their ancestors, with all their heart and soul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They agreed that anyone who refused to seek the Lord, the God of Israel, would be put to death—whether young or old, man or woman.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They shouted out their oath of loyalty to the Lord with trumpets blaring and rams’ horns sounding.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All in Judah were happy about this covenant, for they had entered into it with all their heart. They earnestly sought after God, and they found him. And the Lord gave them rest from their enemies on every side.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Asa even deposed his grandmother Maacah from her position as queen mother because she had made an obscene Asherah pole. He cut down her obscene pole, broke it up, and burned it in the Kidron Valley.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Although the pagan shrines were not removed from Israel, Asa’s heart remained completely faithful throughout his life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He brought into the Temple of God the silver and gold and the various items that he and his father had dedicated.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So there was no more war until the thirty-fifth year of Asa’s reign.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the thirty-sixth year of Asa’s reign, King Baasha of Israel invaded Judah and fortified Ramah in order to prevent anyone from entering or leaving King Asa’s territory in Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Asa responded by removing the silver and gold from the treasuries of the Temple of the Lord and the royal palace. He sent it to King Ben-hadad of Aram, who was ruling in Damascus, along with this message:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Let there be a treaty between you and me like the one between your father and my father. See, I am sending you silver and gold. Break your treaty with King Baasha of Israel so that he will leave me alone.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ben-hadad agreed to King Asa’s request and sent the commanders of his army to attack the towns of Israel. They conquered the towns of Ijon, Dan, Abel-beth-maacah, and all the store cities in Naphtali.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As soon as Baasha of Israel heard what was happening, he abandoned his project of fortifying Ramah and stopped all work on it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King Asa called out all the men of Judah to carry away the building stones and timbers that Baasha had been using to fortify Ramah. Asa used these materials to fortify the towns of Geba and Mizpah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time Hanani the seer came to King Asa and told him, “Because you have put your trust in the king of Aram instead of in the Lord your God, you missed your chance to destroy the army of the king of Aram.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t you remember what happened to the Ethiopians and Libyans and their vast army, with all of their chariots and charioteers? At that time you relied on the Lord, and he handed them over to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The eyes of the Lord search the whole earth in order to strengthen those whose hearts are fully committed to him. What a fool you have been! From now on you will be at war.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Asa became so angry with Hanani for saying this that he threw him into prison and put him in stocks. At that time Asa also began to oppress some of his people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of the events of Asa’s reign, from beginning to end, are recorded in The Book of the Kings of Judah and Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the thirty-ninth year of his reign, Asa developed a serious foot disease. Yet even with the severity of his disease, he did not seek the Lord’s help but turned only to his physicians.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he died in the forty-first year of his reign.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was buried in the tomb he had carved out for himself in the City of David. He was laid on a bed perfumed with sweet spices and fragrant ointments, and the people built a huge funeral fire in his honor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jehoshaphat, Asa’s son, became the next king. He strengthened Judah to stand against any attack from Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He stationed troops in all the fortified towns of Judah, and he assigned additional garrisons to the land of Judah and to the towns of Ephraim that his father, Asa, had captured.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord was with Jehoshaphat because he followed the example of his father’s early years and did not worship the images of Baal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He sought his father’s God and obeyed his commands instead of following the evil practices of the kingdom of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord established Jehoshaphat’s control over the kingdom of Judah. All the people of Judah brought gifts to Jehoshaphat, so he became very wealthy and highly esteemed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was deeply committed to the ways of the Lord. He removed the pagan shrines and Asherah poles from Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the third year of his reign Jehoshaphat sent his officials to teach in all the towns of Judah. These officials included Ben-hail, Obadiah, Zechariah, Nethanel, and Micaiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He sent Levites along with them, including Shemaiah, Nethaniah, Zebadiah, Asahel, Shemiramoth, Jehonathan, Adonijah, Tobijah, and Tob-Adonijah. He also sent out the priests Elishama and Jehoram.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They took copies of the Book of the Law of the Lord and traveled around through all the towns of Judah, teaching the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the fear of the Lord fell over all the surrounding kingdoms so that none of them wanted to declare war on Jehoshaphat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some of the Philistines brought him gifts and silver as tribute, and the Arabs brought 7,700 rams and 7,700 male goats.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jehoshaphat became more and more powerful and built fortresses and storage cities throughout Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He stored numerous supplies in Judah’s towns and stationed an army of seasoned troops at Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His army was enrolled according to ancestral clans.
From Judah there were 300,000 troops organized in units of 1,000, under the command of Adnah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Next in command was Jehohanan, who commanded 280,000 troops.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Next was Amasiah son of Zicri, who volunteered for the Lord’s service, with 200,000 troops under his command.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From Benjamin there were 200,000 troops equipped with bows and shields. They were under the command of Eliada, a veteran soldier.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Next in command was Jehozabad, who commanded 180,000 armed men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the troops stationed in Jerusalem to serve the king, besides those Jehoshaphat stationed in the fortified towns throughout Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat enjoyed great riches and high esteem, and he made an alliance with Ahab of Israel by having his son marry Ahab’s daughter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A few years later he went to Samaria to visit Ahab, who prepared a great banquet for him and his officials. They butchered great numbers of sheep, goats, and cattle for the feast. Then Ahab enticed Jehoshaphat to join forces with him to recover Ramoth-gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Will you go with me to Ramoth-gilead?” King Ahab of Israel asked King Jehoshaphat of Judah.
Jehoshaphat replied, “Why, of course! You and I are as one, and my troops are your troops. We will certainly join you in battle.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jehoshaphat added, “But first let’s find out what the Lord says.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So the king of Israel summoned the prophets, 400 of them, and asked them, “Should we go to war against Ramoth-gilead, or should I hold back?”
They all replied, “Yes, go right ahead! God will give the king victory.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Jehoshaphat asked, “Is there not also a prophet of the Lord here? We should ask him the same question.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king of Israel replied to Jehoshaphat, “There is one more man who could consult the Lord for us, but I hate him. He never prophesies anything but trouble for me! His name is Micaiah son of Imlah.”
Jehoshaphat replied, “That’s not the way a king should talk! Let’s hear what he has to say.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king of Israel called one of his officials and said, “Quick! Bring Micaiah son of Imlah.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Ahab of Israel and King Jehoshaphat of Judah, dressed in their royal robes, were sitting on thrones at the threshing floor near the gate of Samaria. All of Ahab’s prophets were prophesying there in front of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One of them, Zedekiah son of Kenaanah, made some iron horns and proclaimed, “This is what the Lord says: With these horns you will gore the Arameans to death!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the other prophets agreed. “Yes,” they said, “go up to Ramoth-gilead and be victorious, for the Lord will give the king victory!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, the messenger who went to get Micaiah said to him, “Look, all the prophets are promising victory for the king. Be sure that you agree with them and promise success.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Micaiah replied, “As surely as the Lord lives, I will say only what my God says.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When Micaiah arrived before the king, Ahab asked him, “Micaiah, should we go to war against Ramoth-gilead, or should I hold back?”
Micaiah replied sarcastically, “Yes, go up and be victorious, for you will have victory over them!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the king replied sharply, “How many times must I demand that you speak only the truth to me when you speak for the Lord?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Micaiah told him, “In a vision I saw all Israel scattered on the mountains, like sheep without a shepherd. And the Lord said, ‘Their master has been killed. Send them home in peace.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Didn’t I tell you?” the king of Israel exclaimed to Jehoshaphat. “He never prophesies anything but trouble for me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Micaiah continued, “Listen to what the Lord says! I saw the Lord sitting on his throne with all the armies of heaven around him, on his right and on his left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And the Lord said, ‘Who can entice King Ahab of Israel to go into battle against Ramoth-gilead so he can be killed?’
“There were many suggestions,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and finally a spirit approached the Lord and said, ‘I can do it!’
“‘How will you do this?’ the Lord asked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“And the spirit replied, ‘I will go out and inspire all of Ahab’s prophets to speak lies.’
“‘You will succeed,’ said the Lord. ‘Go ahead and do it.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “So you see, the Lord has put a lying spirit in the mouths of your prophets. For the Lord has pronounced your doom.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Zedekiah son of Kenaanah walked up to Micaiah and slapped him across the face. “Since when did the Spirit of the Lord leave me to speak to you?” he demanded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Micaiah replied, “You will find out soon enough when you are trying to hide in some secret room!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Arrest him!” the king of Israel ordered. “Take him back to Amon, the governor of the city, and to my son Joash.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Give them this order from the king: ‘Put this man in prison, and feed him nothing but bread and water until I return safely from the battle!’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Micaiah replied, “If you return safely, it will mean that the Lord has not spoken through me!” Then he added to those standing around, “Everyone mark my words!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So King Ahab of Israel and King Jehoshaphat of Judah led their armies against Ramoth-gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, “As we go into battle, I will disguise myself so no one will recognize me, but you wear your royal robes.” So the king of Israel disguised himself, and they went into battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, the king of Aram had issued these orders to his chariot commanders: “Attack only the king of Israel! Don’t bother with anyone else.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So when the Aramean chariot commanders saw Jehoshaphat in his royal robes, they went after him. “There is the king of Israel!” they shouted. But Jehoshaphat called out, and the Lord saved him. God helped him by turning the attackers away from him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As soon as the chariot commanders realized he was not the king of Israel, they stopped chasing him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: An Aramean soldier, however, randomly shot an arrow at the Israelite troops and hit the king of Israel between the joints of his armor. “Turn the horses and get me out of here!” Ahab groaned to the driver of the chariot. “I’m badly wounded!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The battle raged all that day, and the king of Israel propped himself up in his chariot facing the Arameans. In the evening, just as the sun was setting, he died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When King Jehoshaphat of Judah arrived safely home in Jerusalem,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehu son of Hanani the seer went out to meet him. “Why should you help the wicked and love those who hate the Lord?” he asked the king. “Because of what you have done, the Lord is very angry with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even so, there is some good in you, for you have removed the Asherah poles throughout the land, and you have committed yourself to seeking God.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat lived in Jerusalem, but he went out among the people, traveling from Beersheba to the hill country of Ephraim, encouraging the people to return to the Lord, the God of their ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He appointed judges throughout the nation in all the fortified towns,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and he said to them, “Always think carefully before pronouncing judgment. Remember that you do not judge to please people but to please the Lord. He will be with you when you render the verdict in each case.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Fear the Lord and judge with integrity, for the Lord our God does not tolerate perverted justice, partiality, or the taking of bribes.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In Jerusalem, Jehoshaphat appointed some of the Levites and priests and clan leaders in Israel to serve as judges for cases involving the Lord’s regulations and for civil disputes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were his instructions to them: “You must always act in the fear of the Lord, with faithfulness and an undivided heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whenever a case comes to you from fellow citizens in an outlying town, whether a murder case or some other violation of God’s laws, commands, decrees, or regulations, you must warn them not to sin against the Lord, so that he will not be angry with you and them. Do this and you will not be guilty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Amariah the high priest will have final say in all cases involving the Lord. Zebadiah son of Ishmael, a leader from the tribe of Judah, will have final say in all civil cases. The Levites will assist you in making sure that justice is served. Take courage as you fulfill your duties, and may the Lord be with those who do what is right.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, the armies of the Moabites, Ammonites, and some of the Meunites declared war on Jehoshaphat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Messengers came and told Jehoshaphat, “A vast army from Edom is marching against you from beyond the Dead Sea. They are already at Hazazon-tamar.” (This was another name for En-gedi.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat was terrified by this news and begged the Lord for guidance. He also ordered everyone in Judah to begin fasting.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So people from all the towns of Judah came to Jerusalem to seek the Lord’s help.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat stood before the community of Judah and Jerusalem in front of the new courtyard at the Temple of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He prayed, “O Lord, God of our ancestors, you alone are the God who is in heaven. You are ruler of all the kingdoms of the earth. You are powerful and mighty; no one can stand against you!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: O our God, did you not drive out those who lived in this land when your people Israel arrived? And did you not give this land forever to the descendants of your friend Abraham?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your people settled here and built this Temple to honor your name.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said, ‘Whenever we are faced with any calamity such as war, plague, or famine, we can come to stand in your presence before this Temple where your name is honored. We can cry out to you to save us, and you will hear us and rescue us.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “And now see what the armies of Ammon, Moab, and Mount Seir are doing. You would not let our ancestors invade those nations when Israel left Egypt, so they went around them and did not destroy them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now see how they reward us! For they have come to throw us out of your land, which you gave us as an inheritance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: O our God, won’t you stop them? We are powerless against this mighty army that is about to attack us. We do not know what to do, but we are looking to you for help.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As all the men of Judah stood before the Lord with their little ones, wives, and children,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the Spirit of the Lord came upon one of the men standing there. His name was Jahaziel son of Zechariah, son of Benaiah, son of Jeiel, son of Mattaniah, a Levite who was a descendant of Asaph.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “Listen, all you people of Judah and Jerusalem! Listen, King Jehoshaphat! This is what the Lord says: Do not be afraid! Don’t be discouraged by this mighty army, for the battle is not yours, but God’s.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Tomorrow, march out against them. You will find them coming up through the ascent of Ziz at the end of the valley that opens into the wilderness of Jeruel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But you will not even need to fight. Take your positions; then stand still and watch the Lord’s victory. He is with you, O people of Judah and Jerusalem. Do not be afraid or discouraged. Go out against them tomorrow, for the Lord is with you!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King Jehoshaphat bowed low with his face to the ground. And all the people of Judah and Jerusalem did the same, worshiping the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Levites from the clans of Kohath and Korah stood to praise the Lord, the God of Israel, with a very loud shout.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Early the next morning the army of Judah went out into the wilderness of Tekoa. On the way Jehoshaphat stopped and said, “Listen to me, all you people of Judah and Jerusalem! Believe in the Lord your God, and you will be able to stand firm. Believe in his prophets, and you will succeed.”
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text: At the very moment they began to sing and give praise, the Lord caused the armies of Ammon, Moab, and Mount Seir to start fighting among themselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The armies of Moab and Ammon turned against their allies from Mount Seir and killed every one of them. After they had destroyed the army of Seir, they began attacking each other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So when the army of Judah arrived at the lookout point in the wilderness, all they saw were dead bodies lying on the ground as far as they could see. Not a single one of the enemy had escaped.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Jehoshaphat and his men went out to gather the plunder. They found vast amounts of equipment, clothing, and other valuables—more than they could carry. There was so much plunder that it took them three days just to collect it all!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the fourth day they gathered in the Valley of Blessing, which got its name that day because the people praised and thanked the Lord there. It is still called the Valley of Blessing today.
