verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the men returned to Jerusalem, with Jehoshaphat leading them, overjoyed that the Lord had given them victory over their enemies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They marched into Jerusalem to the music of harps, lyres, and trumpets, and they proceeded to the Temple of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all the surrounding kingdoms heard that the Lord himself had fought against the enemies of Israel, the fear of God came over them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jehoshaphat’s kingdom was at peace, for his God had given him rest on every side.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jehoshaphat ruled over the land of Judah. He was thirty-five years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem twenty-five years. His mother was Azubah, the daughter of Shilhi.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat was a good king, following the ways of his father, Asa. He did what was pleasing in the Lord’s sight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During his reign, however, he failed to remove all the pagan shrines, and the people never fully committed themselves to follow the God of their ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of the events of Jehoshaphat’s reign, from beginning to end, are recorded in The Record of Jehu Son of Hanani, which is included in The Book of the Kings of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some time later King Jehoshaphat of Judah made an alliance with King Ahaziah of Israel, who was very wicked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Together they built a fleet of trading ships at the port of Ezion-geber.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Eliezer son of Dodavahu from Mareshah prophesied against Jehoshaphat. He said, “Because you have allied yourself with King Ahaziah, the Lord will destroy your work.” So the ships met with disaster and never put out to sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jehoshaphat died, he was buried with his ancestors in the City of David. Then his son Jehoram became the next king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoram’s brothers—the other sons of Jehoshaphat—were Azariah, Jehiel, Zechariah, Azariahu, Michael, and Shephatiah; all these were the sons of Jehoshaphat king of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Their father had given each of them valuable gifts of silver, gold, and costly items, and also some of Judah’s fortified towns. However, he designated Jehoram as the next king because he was the oldest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when Jehoram had become solidly established as king, he killed all his brothers and some of the other leaders of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoram was thirty-two years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem eight years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Jehoram followed the example of the kings of Israel and was as wicked as King Ahab, for he had married one of Ahab’s daughters. So Jehoram did what was evil in the Lord’s sight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord did not want to destroy David’s dynasty, for he had made a covenant with David and promised that his descendants would continue to rule, shining like a lamp forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During Jehoram’s reign, the Edomites revolted against Judah and crowned their own king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jehoram went out with his full army and all his chariots. The Edomites surrounded him and his chariot commanders, but he went out at night and attacked them under cover of darkness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even so, Edom has been independent from Judah to this day. The town of Libnah also revolted about that same time. All this happened because Jehoram had abandoned the Lord, the God of his ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had built pagan shrines in the hill country of Judah and had led the people of Jerusalem and Judah to give themselves to pagan gods and to go astray.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Elijah the prophet wrote Jehoram this letter:
“This is what the Lord, the God of your ancestor David, says: You have not followed the good example of your father, Jehoshaphat, or your grandfather King Asa of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Instead, you have been as evil as the kings of Israel. You have led the people of Jerusalem and Judah to worship idols, just as King Ahab did in Israel. And you have even killed your own brothers, men who were better than you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So now the Lord is about to strike you, your people, your children, your wives, and all that is yours with a heavy blow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You yourself will suffer with a severe intestinal disease that will get worse each day until your bowels come out.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord stirred up the Philistines and the Arabs, who lived near the Ethiopians, to attack Jehoram.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They marched against Judah, broke down its defenses, and carried away everything of value in the royal palace, including the king’s sons and his wives. Only his youngest son, Ahaziah, was spared.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After all this, the Lord struck Jehoram with an incurable intestinal disease.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The disease grew worse and worse, and at the end of two years it caused his bowels to come out, and he died in agony. His people did not build a great funeral fire to honor him as they had done for his ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoram was thirty-two years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem eight years. No one was sorry when he died. They buried him in the City of David, but not in the royal cemetery.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the people of Jerusalem made Ahaziah, Jehoram’s youngest son, their next king, since the marauding bands who came with the Arabs had killed all the older sons. So Ahaziah son of Jehoram reigned as king of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahaziah was twenty-two years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem one year. His mother was Athaliah, a granddaughter of King Omri.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahaziah also followed the evil example of King Ahab’s family, for his mother encouraged him in doing wrong.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did what was evil in the Lord’s sight, just as Ahab’s family had done. They even became his advisers after the death of his father, and they led him to ruin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Following their evil advice, Ahaziah joined Joram, the son of King Ahab of Israel, in his war against King Hazael of Aram at Ramoth-gilead. When the Arameans wounded Joram in the battle,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he returned to Jezreel to recover from the wounds he had received at Ramoth. Because Joram was wounded, King Ahaziah of Judah went to Jezreel to visit him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But God had decided that this visit would be Ahaziah’s downfall. While he was there, Ahaziah went out with Joram to meet Jehu grandson of Nimshi, whom the Lord had appointed to destroy the dynasty of Ahab.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While Jehu was executing judgment against the family of Ahab, he happened to meet some of Judah’s officials and Ahaziah’s relatives who were traveling with Ahaziah. So Jehu killed them all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jehu’s men searched for Ahaziah, and they found him hiding in the city of Samaria. They brought him to Jehu, who killed him. Ahaziah was given a decent burial because the people said, “He was the grandson of Jehoshaphat—a man who sought the Lord with all his heart.” But none of the surviving members of Ahaziah’s family was capable of ruling the kingdom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Athaliah, the mother of King Ahaziah of Judah, learned that her son was dead, she began to destroy the rest of Judah’s royal family.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Ahaziah’s sister Jehosheba, the daughter of King Jehoram, took Ahaziah’s infant son, Joash, and stole him away from among the rest of the king’s children, who were about to be killed. She put Joash and his nurse in a bedroom. In this way, Jehosheba, wife of Jehoiada the priest and sister of Ahaziah, hid the child so that Athaliah could not murder him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joash remained hidden in the Temple of God for six years while Athaliah ruled over the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the seventh year of Athaliah’s reign, Jehoiada the priest decided to act. He summoned his courage and made a pact with five army commanders: Azariah son of Jeroham, Ishmael son of Jehohanan, Azariah son of Obed, Maaseiah son of Adaiah, and Elishaphat son of Zicri.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These men traveled secretly throughout Judah and summoned the Levites and clan leaders in all the towns to come to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They all gathered at the Temple of God, where they made a solemn pact with Joash, the young king.
Jehoiada said to them, “Here is the king’s son! The time has come for him to reign! The Lord has promised that a descendant of David will be our king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what you must do. When you priests and Levites come on duty on the Sabbath, a third of you will serve as gatekeepers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Another third will go over to the royal palace, and the final third will be at the Foundation Gate. Everyone else should stay in the courtyards of the Lord’s Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Remember, only the priests and Levites on duty may enter the Temple of the Lord, for they are set apart as holy. The rest of the people must obey the Lord’s instructions and stay outside.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You Levites, form a bodyguard around the king and keep your weapons in hand. Kill anyone who tries to enter the Temple. Stay with the king wherever he goes.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Levites and all the people of Judah did everything as Jehoiada the priest ordered. The commanders took charge of the men reporting for duty that Sabbath, as well as those who were going off duty. Jehoiada the priest did not let anyone go home after their shift ended.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jehoiada supplied the commanders with the spears and the large and small shields that had once belonged to King David and were stored in the Temple of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He stationed all the people around the king, with their weapons ready. They formed a line from the south side of the Temple around to the north side and all around the altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jehoiada and his sons brought out Joash, the king’s son, placed the crown on his head, and presented him with a copy of God’s laws. They anointed him and proclaimed him king, and everyone shouted, “Long live the king!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Athaliah heard the noise of the people running and the shouts of praise to the king, she hurried to the Lord’s Temple to see what was happening.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When she arrived, she saw the newly crowned king standing in his place of authority by the pillar at the Temple entrance. The commanders and trumpeters were surrounding him, and people from all over the land were rejoicing and blowing trumpets. Singers with musical instruments were leading the people in a great celebration. When Athaliah saw all this, she tore her clothes in despair and shouted, “Treason! Treason!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jehoiada the priest ordered the commanders who were in charge of the troops, “Take her to the soldiers in front of the Temple, and kill anyone who tries to rescue her.” For the priest had said, “She must not be killed in the Temple of the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they seized her and led her out to the entrance of the Horse Gate on the palace grounds, and they killed her there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jehoiada made a covenant between himself and the king and the people that they would be the Lord’s people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And all the people went over to the temple of Baal and tore it down. They demolished the altars and smashed the idols, and they killed Mattan the priest of Baal in front of the altars.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoiada now put the priests and Levites in charge of the Temple of the Lord, following all the directions given by David. He also commanded them to present burnt offerings to the Lord, as prescribed by the Law of Moses, and to sing and rejoice as David had instructed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also stationed gatekeepers at the gates of the Lord’s Temple to keep out those who for any reason were ceremonially unclean.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the commanders, nobles, rulers, and all the people of the land escorted the king from the Temple of the Lord. They went through the upper gate and into the palace, and they seated the king on the royal throne.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So all the people of the land rejoiced, and the city was peaceful because Athaliah had been killed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joash was seven years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem forty years. His mother was Zibiah from Beersheba.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joash did what was pleasing in the Lord’s sight throughout the lifetime of Jehoiada the priest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoiada chose two wives for Joash, and he had sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At one point Joash decided to repair and restore the Temple of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He summoned the priests and Levites and gave them these instructions: “Go to all the towns of Judah and collect the required annual offerings, so that we can repair the Temple of your God. Do not delay!” But the Levites did not act immediately.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king called for Jehoiada the high priest and asked him, “Why haven’t you demanded that the Levites go out and collect the Temple taxes from the towns of Judah and from Jerusalem? Moses, the servant of the Lord, levied this tax on the community of Israel in order to maintain the Tabernacle of the Covenant.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Over the years the followers of wicked Athaliah had broken into the Temple of God, and they had used all the dedicated things from the Temple of the Lord to worship the images of Baal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So now the king ordered a chest to be made and set outside the gate leading to the Temple of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then a proclamation was sent throughout Judah and Jerusalem, telling the people to bring to the Lord the tax that Moses, the servant of God, had required of the Israelites in the wilderness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This pleased all the leaders and the people, and they gladly brought their money and filled the chest with it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whenever the chest became full, the Levites would carry it to the king’s officials. Then the court secretary and an officer of the high priest would come and empty the chest and take it back to the Temple again. This went on day after day, and a large amount of money was collected.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king and Jehoiada gave the money to the construction supervisors, who hired masons and carpenters to restore the Temple of the Lord. They also hired metalworkers, who made articles of iron and bronze for the Lord’s Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men in charge of the renovation worked hard and made steady progress. They restored the Temple of God according to its original design and strengthened it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all the repairs were finished, they brought the remaining money to the king and Jehoiada. It was used to make various articles for the Temple of the Lord—articles for worship services and for burnt offerings, including ladles and other articles made of gold and silver. And the burnt offerings were sacrificed continually in the Temple of the Lord during the lifetime of Jehoiada the priest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoiada lived to a very old age, finally dying at 130.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was buried among the kings in the City of David, because he had done so much good in Israel for God and his Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But after Jehoiada’s death, the leaders of Judah came and bowed before King Joash and persuaded him to listen to their advice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They decided to abandon the Temple of the Lord, the God of their ancestors, and they worshiped Asherah poles and idols instead! Because of this sin, divine anger fell on Judah and Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yet the Lord sent prophets to bring them back to him. The prophets warned them, but still the people would not listen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Spirit of God came upon Zechariah son of Jehoiada the priest. He stood before the people and said, “This is what God says: Why do you disobey the Lord’s commands and keep yourselves from prospering? You have abandoned the Lord, and now he has abandoned you!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the leaders plotted to kill Zechariah, and King Joash ordered that they stone him to death in the courtyard of the Lord’s Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That was how King Joash repaid Jehoiada for his loyalty—by killing his son. Zechariah’s last words as he died were, “May the Lord see what they are doing and avenge my death!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the spring of the year the Aramean army marched against Joash. They invaded Judah and Jerusalem and killed all the leaders of the nation. Then they sent all the plunder back to their king in Damascus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Although the Arameans attacked with only a small army, the Lord helped them conquer the much larger army of Judah. The people of Judah had abandoned the Lord, the God of their ancestors, so judgment was carried out against Joash.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Arameans withdrew, leaving Joash severely wounded. But his own officials plotted to kill him for murdering the son of Jehoiada the priest. They assassinated him as he lay in bed. Then he was buried in the City of David, but not in the royal cemetery.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The assassins were Jozacar, the son of an Ammonite woman named Shimeath, and Jehozabad, the son of a Moabite woman named Shomer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The account of the sons of Joash, the prophecies about him, and the record of his restoration of the Temple of God are written in The Commentary on the Book of the Kings. His son Amaziah became the next king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Amaziah was twenty-five years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem twenty-nine years. His mother was Jehoaddin from Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Amaziah did what was pleasing in the Lord’s sight, but not wholeheartedly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Amaziah was well established as king, he executed the officials who had assassinated his father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, he did not kill the children of the assassins, for he obeyed the command of the Lord as written by Moses in the Book of the Law: “Parents must not be put to death for the sins of their children, nor children for the sins of their parents. Those deserving to die must be put to death for their own crimes.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Amaziah organized the army, assigning generals and captains for all Judah and Benjamin. He took a census and found that he had an army of 300,000 select troops, twenty years old and older, all trained in the use of spear and shield.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also paid about 7,500 pounds of silver to hire 100,000 experienced fighting men from Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But a man of God came to him and said, “Your Majesty, do not hire troops from Israel, for the Lord is not with Israel. He will not help those people of Ephraim!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you let them go with your troops into battle, you will be defeated by the enemy no matter how well you fight. God will overthrow you, for he has the power to help you or to trip you up.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Amaziah asked the man of God, “But what about all that silver I paid to hire the army of Israel?”
The man of God replied, “The Lord is able to give you much more than this!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Amaziah discharged the hired troops and sent them back to Ephraim. This made them very angry with Judah, and they returned home in a great rage.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Amaziah summoned his courage and led his army to the Valley of Salt, where they killed 10,000 Edomite troops from Seir.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They captured another 10,000 and took them to the top of a cliff and threw them off, dashing them to pieces on the rocks below.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, the hired troops that Amaziah had sent home raided several of the towns of Judah between Samaria and Beth-horon. They killed 3,000 people and carried off great quantities of plunder.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When King Amaziah returned from slaughtering the Edomites, he brought with him idols taken from the people of Seir. He set them up as his own gods, bowed down in front of them, and offered sacrifices to them!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This made the Lord very angry, and he sent a prophet to ask, “Why do you turn to gods who could not even save their own people from you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But the king interrupted him and said, “Since when have I made you the king’s counselor? Be quiet now before I have you killed!”
So the prophet stopped with this warning: “I know that God has determined to destroy you because you have done this and have refused to accept my counsel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After consulting with his advisers, King Amaziah of Judah sent this challenge to Israel’s king Jehoash, the son of Jehoahaz and grandson of Jehu: “Come and meet me in battle!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But King Jehoash of Israel replied to King Amaziah of Judah with this story: “Out in the Lebanon mountains, a thistle sent a message to a mighty cedar tree: ‘Give your daughter in marriage to my son.’ But just then a wild animal of Lebanon came by and stepped on the thistle, crushing it!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You are saying, ‘I have defeated Edom,’ and you are very proud of it. But my advice is to stay at home. Why stir up trouble that will only bring disaster on you and the people of Judah?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Amaziah refused to listen, for God was determined to destroy him for turning to the gods of Edom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So King Jehoash of Israel mobilized his army against King Amaziah of Judah. The two armies drew up their battle lines at Beth-shemesh in Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Judah was routed by the army of Israel, and its army scattered and fled for home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Jehoash of Israel captured Judah’s king, Amaziah son of Joash and grandson of Ahaziah, at Beth-shemesh. Then he brought him to Jerusalem, where he demolished 600 feet of Jerusalem’s wall, from the Ephraim Gate to the Corner Gate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He carried off all the gold and silver and all the articles from the Temple of God that had been in the care of Obed-edom. He also seized the treasures of the royal palace, along with hostages, and then returned to Samaria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Amaziah of Judah lived for fifteen years after the death of King Jehoash of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of the events in Amaziah’s reign, from beginning to end, are recorded in The Book of the Kings of Judah and Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Amaziah turned away from the Lord, there was a conspiracy against his life in Jerusalem, and he fled to Lachish. But his enemies sent assassins after him, and they killed him there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They brought his body back on a horse, and he was buried with his ancestors in the City of David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people of Judah had crowned Amaziah’s sixteen-year-old son, Uzziah, as king in place of his father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After his father’s death, Uzziah rebuilt the town of Elath and restored it to Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Uzziah was sixteen years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem fifty-two years. His mother was Jecoliah from Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did what was pleasing in the Lord’s sight, just as his father, Amaziah, had done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Uzziah sought God during the days of Zechariah, who taught him to fear God. And as long as the king sought guidance from the Lord, God gave him success.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Uzziah declared war on the Philistines and broke down the walls of Gath, Jabneh, and Ashdod. Then he built new towns in the Ashdod area and in other parts of Philistia.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God helped him in his wars against the Philistines, his battles with the Arabs of Gur, and his wars with the Meunites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Meunites paid annual tribute to him, and his fame spread even to Egypt, for he had become very powerful.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Uzziah built fortified towers in Jerusalem at the Corner Gate, at the Valley Gate, and at the angle in the wall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also constructed forts in the wilderness and dug many water cisterns, because he kept great herds of livestock in the foothills of Judah and on the plains. He was also a man who loved the soil. He had many workers who cared for his farms and vineyards, both on the hillsides and in the fertile valleys.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Uzziah had an army of well-trained warriors, ready to march into battle, unit by unit. This army had been mustered and organized by Jeiel, the secretary of the army, and his assistant, Maaseiah. They were under the direction of Hananiah, one of the king’s officials.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These regiments of mighty warriors were commanded by 2,600 clan leaders.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The army consisted of 307,500 men, all elite troops. They were prepared to assist the king against any enemy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Uzziah provided the entire army with shields, spears, helmets, coats of mail, bows, and sling stones.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And he built structures on the walls of Jerusalem, designed by experts to protect those who shot arrows and hurled large stones from the towers and the corners of the wall. His fame spread far and wide, for the Lord gave him marvelous help, and he became very powerful.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when he had become powerful, he also became proud, which led to his downfall. He sinned against the Lord his God by entering the sanctuary of the Lord’s Temple and personally burning incense on the incense altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Azariah the high priest went in after him with eighty other priests of the Lord, all brave men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They confronted King Uzziah and said, “It is not for you, Uzziah, to burn incense to the Lord. That is the work of the priests alone, the descendants of Aaron who are set apart for this work. Get out of the sanctuary, for you have sinned. The Lord God will not honor you for this!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Uzziah, who was holding an incense burner, became furious. But as he was standing there raging at the priests before the incense altar in the Lord’s Temple, leprosy suddenly broke out on his forehead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Azariah the high priest and all the other priests saw the leprosy, they rushed him out. And the king himself was eager to get out because the Lord had struck him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So King Uzziah had leprosy until the day he died. He lived in isolation in a separate house, for he was excluded from the Temple of the Lord. His son Jotham was put in charge of the royal palace, and he governed the people of the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of the events of Uzziah’s reign, from beginning to end, are recorded by the prophet Isaiah son of Amoz.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Uzziah died, he was buried with his ancestors; his grave was in a nearby burial field belonging to the kings, for the people said, “He had leprosy.” And his son Jotham became the next king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jotham was twenty-five years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem sixteen years. His mother was Jerusha, the daughter of Zadok.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jotham did what was pleasing in the Lord’s sight. He did everything his father, Uzziah, had done, except that Jotham did not sin by entering the Temple of the Lord. But the people continued in their corrupt ways.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jotham rebuilt the upper gate of the Temple of the Lord. He also did extensive rebuilding on the wall at the hill of Ophel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He built towns in the hill country of Judah and constructed fortresses and towers in the wooded areas.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jotham went to war against the Ammonites and conquered them. Over the next three years he received from them an annual tribute of 7,500 pounds of silver, 50,000 bushels of wheat, and 50,000 bushels of barley.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Jotham became powerful because he was careful to live in obedience to the Lord his God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of the events of Jotham’s reign, including all his wars and other activities, are recorded in The Book of the Kings of Israel and Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was twenty-five years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem sixteen years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jotham died, he was buried in the City of David. And his son Ahaz became the next king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahaz was twenty years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem sixteen years. He did not do what was pleasing in the sight of the Lord, as his ancestor David had done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Instead, he followed the example of the kings of Israel. He cast metal images for the worship of Baal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He offered sacrifices in the valley of Ben-Hinnom, even sacrificing his own sons in the fire. In this way, he followed the detestable practices of the pagan nations the Lord had driven from the land ahead of the Israelites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He offered sacrifices and burned incense at the pagan shrines and on the hills and under every green tree.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because of all this, the Lord his God allowed the king of Aram to defeat Ahaz and to exile large numbers of his people to Damascus. The armies of the king of Israel also defeated Ahaz and inflicted many casualties on his army.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In a single day Pekah son of Remaliah, Israel’s king, killed 120,000 of Judah’s troops, all of them experienced warriors, because they had abandoned the Lord, the God of their ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Zicri, a warrior from Ephraim, killed Maaseiah, the king’s son; Azrikam, the king’s palace commander; and Elkanah, the king’s second-in-command.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The armies of Israel captured 200,000 women and children from Judah and seized tremendous amounts of plunder, which they took back to Samaria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But a prophet of the Lord named Oded was there in Samaria when the army of Israel returned home. He went out to meet them and said, “The Lord, the God of your ancestors, was angry with Judah and let you defeat them. But you have gone too far, killing them without mercy, and all heaven is disturbed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And now you are planning to make slaves of these people from Judah and Jerusalem. What about your own sins against the Lord your God?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Listen to me and return these prisoners you have taken, for they are your own relatives. Watch out, because now the Lord’s fierce anger has been turned against you!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then some of the leaders of Israel—Azariah son of Jehohanan, Berekiah son of Meshillemoth, Jehizkiah son of Shallum, and Amasa son of Hadlai—agreed with this and confronted the men returning from battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You must not bring the prisoners here!” they declared. “We cannot afford to add to our sins and guilt. Our guilt is already great, and the Lord’s fierce anger is already turned against Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the warriors released the prisoners and handed over the plunder in the sight of the leaders and all the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the four men just mentioned by name came forward and distributed clothes from the plunder to the prisoners who were naked. They provided clothing and sandals to wear, gave them enough food and drink, and dressed their wounds with olive oil. They put those who were weak on donkeys and took all the prisoners back to their own people in Jericho, the city of palms. Then they returned to Samaria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time King Ahaz of Judah asked the king of Assyria for help.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The armies of Edom had again invaded Judah and taken captives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Philistines had raided towns located in the foothills of Judah and in the Negev of Judah. They had already captured and occupied Beth-shemesh, Aijalon, Gederoth, Soco with its villages, Timnah with its villages, and Gimzo with its villages.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord was humbling Judah because of King Ahaz of Judah, for he had encouraged his people to sin and had been utterly unfaithful to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So when King Tiglath-pileser of Assyria arrived, he attacked Ahaz instead of helping him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahaz took valuable items from the Lord’s Temple, the royal palace, and from the homes of his officials and gave them to the king of Assyria as tribute. But this did not help him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even during this time of trouble, King Ahaz continued to reject the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He offered sacrifices to the gods of Damascus who had defeated him, for he said, “Since these gods helped the kings of Aram, they will help me, too, if I sacrifice to them.” But instead, they led to his ruin and the ruin of all Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king took the various articles from the Temple of God and broke them into pieces. He shut the doors of the Lord’s Temple so that no one could worship there, and he set up altars to pagan gods in every corner of Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made pagan shrines in all the towns of Judah for offering sacrifices to other gods. In this way, he aroused the anger of the Lord, the God of his ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of the events of Ahaz’s reign and everything he did, from beginning to end, are recorded in The Book of the Kings of Judah and Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Ahaz died, he was buried in Jerusalem but not in the royal cemetery of the kings of Judah. Then his son Hezekiah became the next king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah was twenty-five years old when he became the king of Judah, and he reigned in Jerusalem twenty-nine years. His mother was Abijah, the daughter of Zechariah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did what was pleasing in the Lord’s sight, just as his ancestor David had done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the very first month of the first year of his reign, Hezekiah reopened the doors of the Temple of the Lord and repaired them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He summoned the priests and Levites to meet him at the courtyard east of the Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to them, “Listen to me, you Levites! Purify yourselves, and purify the Temple of the Lord, the God of your ancestors. Remove all the defiled things from the sanctuary.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Our ancestors were unfaithful and did what was evil in the sight of the Lord our God. They abandoned the Lord and his dwelling place; they turned their backs on him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They also shut the doors to the Temple’s entry room, and they snuffed out the lamps. They stopped burning incense and presenting burnt offerings at the sanctuary of the God of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “That is why the Lord’s anger has fallen upon Judah and Jerusalem. He has made them an object of dread, horror, and ridicule, as you can see with your own eyes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because of this, our fathers have been killed in battle, and our sons and daughters and wives have been captured.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now I will make a covenant with the Lord, the God of Israel, so that his fierce anger will turn away from us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My sons, do not neglect your duties any longer! The Lord has chosen you to stand in his presence, to minister to him, and to lead the people in worship and present offerings to him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then these Levites got right to work:
From the clan of Kohath: Mahath son of Amasai and Joel son of Azariah.
From the clan of Merari: Kish son of Abdi and Azariah son of Jehallelel.
From the clan of Gershon: Joah son of Zimmah and Eden son of Joah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
From the family of Elizaphan: Shimri and Jeiel.
From the family of Asaph: Zechariah and Mattaniah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
From the family of Heman: Jehiel and Shimei.
From the family of Jeduthun: Shemaiah and Uzziel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These men called together their fellow Levites, and they all purified themselves. Then they began to cleanse the Temple of the Lord, just as the king had commanded. They were careful to follow all the Lord’s instructions in their work.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests went into the sanctuary of the Temple of the Lord to cleanse it, and they took out to the Temple courtyard all the defiled things they found. From there the Levites carted it all out to the Kidron Valley.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They began the work in early spring, on the first day of the new year, and in eight days they had reached the entry room of the Lord’s Temple. Then they purified the Temple of the Lord itself, which took another eight days. So the entire task was completed in sixteen days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Levites went to King Hezekiah and gave him this report: “We have cleansed the entire Temple of the Lord, the altar of burnt offering with all its utensils, and the table of the Bread of the Presence with all its utensils.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We have also recovered all the items discarded by King Ahaz when he was unfaithful and closed the Temple. They are now in front of the altar of the Lord, purified and ready for use.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Early the next morning King Hezekiah gathered the city officials and went to the Temple of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They brought seven bulls, seven rams, and seven male lambs as a burnt offering, together with seven male goats as a sin offering for the kingdom, for the Temple, and for Judah. The king commanded the priests, who were descendants of Aaron, to sacrifice the animals on the altar of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they killed the bulls, and the priests took the blood and sprinkled it on the altar. Next they killed the rams and sprinkled their blood on the altar. And finally, they did the same with the male lambs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The male goats for the sin offering were then brought before the king and the assembly of people, who laid their hands on them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests then killed the goats as a sin offering and sprinkled their blood on the altar to make atonement for the sins of all Israel. The king had specifically commanded that this burnt offering and sin offering should be made for all Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Hezekiah then stationed the Levites at the Temple of the Lord with cymbals, lyres, and harps. He obeyed all the commands that the Lord had given to King David through Gad, the king’s seer, and the prophet Nathan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Levites then took their positions around the Temple with the instruments of David, and the priests took their positions with the trumpets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Hezekiah ordered that the burnt offering be placed on the altar. As the burnt offering was presented, songs of praise to the Lord were begun, accompanied by the trumpets and other instruments of David, the former king of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The entire assembly worshiped the Lord as the singers sang and the trumpets blew, until all the burnt offerings were finished.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king and everyone with him bowed down in worship.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Hezekiah and the officials ordered the Levites to praise the Lord with the psalms written by David and by Asaph the seer. So they offered joyous praise and bowed down in worship.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Hezekiah declared, “Now that you have consecrated yourselves to the Lord, bring your sacrifices and thanksgiving offerings to the Temple of the Lord.” So the people brought their sacrifices and thanksgiving offerings, and all whose hearts were willing brought burnt offerings, too.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people brought to the Lord 70 bulls, 100 rams, and 200 male lambs for burnt offerings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They also brought 600 cattle and 3,000 sheep and goats as sacred offerings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But there were too few priests to prepare all the burnt offerings. So their relatives the Levites helped them until the work was finished and more priests had been purified, for the Levites had been more conscientious about purifying themselves than the priests had been.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There was an abundance of burnt offerings, along with the usual liquid offerings, and a great deal of fat from the many peace offerings.
So the Temple of the Lord was restored to service.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Hezekiah and all the people rejoiced because of what God had done for the people, for everything had been accomplished so quickly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Hezekiah now sent word to all Israel and Judah, and he wrote letters of invitation to the people of Ephraim and Manasseh. He asked everyone to come to the Temple of the Lord at Jerusalem to celebrate the Passover of the Lord, the God of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king, his officials, and all the community of Jerusalem decided to celebrate Passover a month later than usual.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They were unable to celebrate it at the prescribed time because not enough priests could be purified by then, and the people had not yet assembled at Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This plan for keeping the Passover seemed right to the king and all the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they sent a proclamation throughout all Israel, from Beersheba in the south to Dan in the north, inviting everyone to come to Jerusalem to celebrate the Passover of the Lord, the God of Israel. The people had not been celebrating it in great numbers as required in the Law.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
At the king’s command, runners were sent throughout Israel and Judah. They carried letters that said:
“O people of Israel, return to the Lord, the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Israel, so that he will return to the few of us who have survived the conquest of the Assyrian kings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not be like your ancestors and relatives who abandoned the Lord, the God of their ancestors, and became an object of derision, as you yourselves can see.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not be stubborn, as they were, but submit yourselves to the Lord. Come to his Temple, which he has set apart as holy forever. Worship the Lord your God so that his fierce anger will turn away from you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “For if you return to the Lord, your relatives and your children will be treated mercifully by their captors, and they will be able to return to this land. For the Lord your God is gracious and merciful. If you return to him, he will not continue to turn his face from you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The runners went from town to town throughout Ephraim and Manasseh and as far as the territory of Zebulun. But most of the people just laughed at the runners and made fun of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, some people from Asher, Manasseh, and Zebulun humbled themselves and went to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the same time, God’s hand was on the people in the land of Judah, giving them all one heart to obey the orders of the king and his officials, who were following the word of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So a huge crowd assembled at Jerusalem in midspring to celebrate the Festival of Unleavened Bread.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They set to work and removed the pagan altars from Jerusalem. They took away all the incense altars and threw them into the Kidron Valley.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the fourteenth day of the second month, one month later than usual, the people slaughtered the Passover lamb. This shamed the priests and Levites, so they purified themselves and brought burnt offerings to the Temple of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they took their places at the Temple as prescribed in the Law of Moses, the man of God. The Levites brought the sacrificial blood to the priests, who then sprinkled it on the altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Since many of the people had not purified themselves, the Levites had to slaughter their Passover lamb for them, to set them apart for the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Most of those who came from Ephraim, Manasseh, Issachar, and Zebulun had not purified themselves. But King Hezekiah prayed for them, and they were allowed to eat the Passover meal anyway, even though this was contrary to the requirements of the Law. For Hezekiah said, “May the Lord, who is good, pardon those
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: who decide to follow the Lord, the God of their ancestors, even though they are not properly cleansed for the ceremony.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord listened to Hezekiah’s prayer and healed the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the people of Israel who were present in Jerusalem joyously celebrated the Festival of Unleavened Bread for seven days. Each day the Levites and priests sang to the Lord, accompanied by loud instruments.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah encouraged all the Levites regarding the skill they displayed as they served the Lord. The celebration continued for seven days. Peace offerings were sacrificed, and the people gave thanks to the Lord, the God of their ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The entire assembly then decided to continue the festival another seven days, so they celebrated joyfully for another week.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Hezekiah gave the people 1,000 bulls and 7,000 sheep and goats for offerings, and the officials donated 1,000 bulls and 10,000 sheep and goats. Meanwhile, many more priests purified themselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The entire assembly of Judah rejoiced, including the priests, the Levites, all who came from the land of Israel, the foreigners who came to the festival, and all those who lived in Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was great joy in the city, for Jerusalem had not seen a celebration like this one since the days of Solomon, King David’s son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the priests and Levites stood and blessed the people, and God heard their prayer from his holy dwelling in heaven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the festival ended, the Israelites who attended went to all the towns of Judah, Benjamin, Ephraim, and Manasseh, and they smashed all the sacred pillars, cut down the Asherah poles, and removed the pagan shrines and altars. After this, the Israelites returned to their own towns and homes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah then organized the priests and Levites into divisions to offer the burnt offerings and peace offerings, and to worship and give thanks and praise to the Lord at the gates of the Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king also made a personal contribution of animals for the daily morning and evening burnt offerings, the weekly Sabbath festivals, the monthly new moon festivals, and the annual festivals as prescribed in the Law of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In addition, he required the people in Jerusalem to bring a portion of their goods to the priests and Levites, so they could devote themselves fully to the Law of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the people of Israel heard these requirements, they responded generously by bringing the first share of their grain, new wine, olive oil, honey, and all the produce of their fields. They brought a large quantity—a tithe of all they produced.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people who had moved to Judah from Israel, and the people of Judah themselves, brought in the tithes of their cattle, sheep, and goats and a tithe of the things that had been dedicated to the Lord their God, and they piled them up in great heaps.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They began piling them up in late spring, and the heaps continued to grow until early autumn.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Hezekiah and his officials came and saw these huge piles, they thanked the Lord and his people Israel!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Where did all this come from?” Hezekiah asked the priests and Levites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Azariah the high priest, from the family of Zadok, replied, “Since the people began bringing their gifts to the Lord’s Temple, we have had enough to eat and plenty to spare. The Lord has blessed his people, and all this is left over.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah ordered that storerooms be prepared in the Temple of the Lord. When this was done,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the people faithfully brought all the gifts, tithes, and other items dedicated for use in the Temple. Conaniah the Levite was put in charge, assisted by his brother Shimei.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The supervisors under them were Jehiel, Azaziah, Nahath, Asahel, Jerimoth, Jozabad, Eliel, Ismakiah, Mahath, and Benaiah. These appointments were made by King Hezekiah and Azariah, the chief official in the Temple of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Kore son of Imnah the Levite, who was the gatekeeper at the East Gate, was put in charge of distributing the voluntary offerings given to God, the gifts, and the things that had been dedicated to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His faithful assistants were Eden, Miniamin, Jeshua, Shemaiah, Amariah, and Shecaniah. They distributed the gifts among the families of priests in their towns by their divisions, dividing the gifts fairly among old and young alike.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They distributed the gifts to all males three years old or older, regardless of their place in the genealogical records. The distribution went to all who would come to the Lord’s Temple to perform their daily duties according to their divisions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They distributed gifts to the priests who were listed by their families in the genealogical records, and to the Levites twenty years old or older who were listed according to their jobs and their divisions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Food allotments were also given to the families of all those listed in the genealogical records, including their little babies, wives, sons, and daughters. For they had all been faithful in purifying themselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for the priests, the descendants of Aaron, who were living in the open villages around the towns, men were appointed by name to distribute portions to every male among the priests and to all the Levites listed in the genealogical records.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In this way, King Hezekiah handled the distribution throughout all Judah, doing what was pleasing and good in the sight of the Lord his God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In all that he did in the service of the Temple of God and in his efforts to follow God’s laws and commands, Hezekiah sought his God wholeheartedly. As a result, he was very successful.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Hezekiah had faithfully carried out this work, King Sennacherib of Assyria invaded Judah. He laid siege to the fortified towns, giving orders for his army to break through their walls.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Hezekiah realized that Sennacherib also intended to attack Jerusalem,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he consulted with his officials and military advisers, and they decided to stop the flow of the springs outside the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They organized a huge work crew to stop the flow of the springs, cutting off the brook that ran through the fields. For they said, “Why should the kings of Assyria come here and find plenty of water?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Hezekiah worked hard at repairing all the broken sections of the wall, erecting towers, and constructing a second wall outside the first. He also reinforced the supporting terraces in the City of David and manufactured large numbers of weapons and shields.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He appointed military officers over the people and assembled them before him in the square at the city gate. Then Hezekiah encouraged them by saying:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Be strong and courageous! Don’t be afraid or discouraged because of the king of Assyria or his mighty army, for there is a power far greater on our side!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He may have a great army, but they are merely men. We have the Lord our God to help us and to fight our battles for us!” Hezekiah’s words greatly encouraged the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While King Sennacherib of Assyria was still besieging the town of Lachish, he sent his officers to Jerusalem with this message for Hezekiah and all the people in the city:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what King Sennacherib of Assyria says: What are you trusting in that makes you think you can survive my siege of Jerusalem?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah has said, ‘The Lord our God will rescue us from the king of Assyria.’ Surely Hezekiah is misleading you, sentencing you to death by famine and thirst!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t you realize that Hezekiah is the very person who destroyed all the Lord’s shrines and altars? He commanded Judah and Jerusalem to worship only at the altar at the Temple and to offer sacrifices on it alone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Surely you must realize what I and the other kings of Assyria before me have done to all the people of the earth! Were any of the gods of those nations able to rescue their people from my power?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Which of their gods was able to rescue its people from the destructive power of my predecessors? What makes you think your God can rescue you from me?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t let Hezekiah deceive you! Don’t let him fool you like this! I say it again—no god of any nation or kingdom has ever yet been able to rescue his people from me or my ancestors. How much less will your God rescue you from my power!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Sennacherib’s officers further mocked the Lord God and his servant Hezekiah, heaping insult upon insult.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king also sent letters scorning the Lord, the God of Israel. He wrote, “Just as the gods of all the other nations failed to rescue their people from my power, so the God of Hezekiah will also fail.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Assyrian officials who brought the letters shouted this in Hebrew to the people gathered on the walls of the city, trying to terrify them so it would be easier to capture the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These officers talked about the God of Jerusalem as though he were one of the pagan gods, made by human hands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King Hezekiah and the prophet Isaiah son of Amoz cried out in prayer to God in heaven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord sent an angel who destroyed the Assyrian army with all its commanders and officers. So Sennacherib was forced to return home in disgrace to his own land. And when he entered the temple of his god, some of his own sons killed him there with a sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That is how the Lord rescued Hezekiah and the people of Jerusalem from King Sennacherib of Assyria and from all the others who threatened them. So there was peace throughout the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From then on King Hezekiah became highly respected among all the surrounding nations, and many gifts for the Lord arrived at Jerusalem, with valuable presents for King Hezekiah, too.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: About that time Hezekiah became deathly ill. He prayed to the Lord, who healed him and gave him a miraculous sign.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Hezekiah did not respond appropriately to the kindness shown him, and he became proud. So the Lord’s anger came against him and against Judah and Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Hezekiah humbled himself and repented of his pride, as did the people of Jerusalem. So the Lord’s anger did not fall on them during Hezekiah’s lifetime.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah was very wealthy and highly honored. He built special treasury buildings for his silver, gold, precious stones, and spices, and for his shields and other valuable items.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also constructed many storehouses for his grain, new wine, and olive oil; and he made many stalls for his cattle and pens for his flocks of sheep and goats.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He built many towns and acquired vast flocks and herds, for God had given him great wealth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He blocked up the upper spring of Gihon and brought the water down through a tunnel to the west side of the City of David. And so he succeeded in everything he did.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, when ambassadors arrived from Babylon to ask about the remarkable events that had taken place in the land, God withdrew from Hezekiah in order to test him and to see what was really in his heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of the events in Hezekiah’s reign and his acts of devotion are recorded in The Vision of the Prophet Isaiah Son of Amoz, which is included in The Book of the Kings of Judah and Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Hezekiah died, he was buried in the upper area of the royal cemetery, and all Judah and Jerusalem honored him at his death. And his son Manasseh became the next king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Manasseh was twelve years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem fifty-five years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did what was evil in the Lord’s sight, following the detestable practices of the pagan nations that the Lord had driven from the land ahead of the Israelites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He rebuilt the pagan shrines his father, Hezekiah, had broken down. He constructed altars for the images of Baal and set up Asherah poles. He also bowed before all the powers of the heavens and worshiped them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He built pagan altars in the Temple of the Lord, the place where the Lord had said, “My name will remain in Jerusalem forever.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He built these altars for all the powers of the heavens in both courtyards of the Lord’s Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Manasseh also sacrificed his own sons in the fire in the valley of Ben-Hinnom. He practiced sorcery, divination, and witchcraft, and he consulted with mediums and psychics. He did much that was evil in the Lord’s sight, arousing his anger.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Manasseh even took a carved idol he had made and set it up in God’s Temple, the very place where God had told David and his son Solomon: “My name will be honored forever in this Temple and in Jerusalem—the city I have chosen from among all the tribes of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If the Israelites will be careful to obey my commands—all the laws, decrees, and regulations given through Moses—I will not send them into exile from this land that I set aside for your ancestors.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Manasseh led the people of Judah and Jerusalem to do even more evil than the pagan nations that the Lord had destroyed when the people of Israel entered the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord spoke to Manasseh and his people, but they ignored all his warnings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord sent the commanders of the Assyrian armies, and they took Manasseh prisoner. They put a ring through his nose, bound him in bronze chains, and led him away to Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But while in deep distress, Manasseh sought the Lord his God and sincerely humbled himself before the God of his ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And when he prayed, the Lord listened to him and was moved by his request. So the Lord brought Manasseh back to Jerusalem and to his kingdom. Then Manasseh finally realized that the Lord alone is God!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this Manasseh rebuilt the outer wall of the City of David, from west of the Gihon Spring in the Kidron Valley to the Fish Gate, and continuing around the hill of Ophel. He built the wall very high. And he stationed his military officers in all of the fortified towns of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Manasseh also removed the foreign gods and the idol from the Lord’s Temple. He tore down all the altars he had built on the hill where the Temple stood and all the altars that were in Jerusalem, and he dumped them outside the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he restored the altar of the Lord and sacrificed peace offerings and thanksgiving offerings on it. He also encouraged the people of Judah to worship the Lord, the God of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, the people still sacrificed at the pagan shrines, though only to the Lord their God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of the events of Manasseh’s reign, his prayer to God, and the words the seers spoke to him in the name of the Lord, the God of Israel, are recorded in The Book of the Kings of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Manasseh’s prayer, the account of the way God answered him, and an account of all his sins and unfaithfulness are recorded in The Record of the Seers. It includes a list of the locations where he built pagan shrines and set up Asherah poles and idols before he humbled himself and repented.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Manasseh died, he was buried in his palace. Then his son Amon became the next king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Amon was twenty-two years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem two years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did what was evil in the Lord’s sight, just as his father, Manasseh, had done. He worshiped and sacrificed to all the idols his father had made.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But unlike his father, he did not humble himself before the Lord. Instead, Amon sinned even more.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Amon’s own officials conspired against him and assassinated him in his palace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the people of the land killed all those who had conspired against King Amon, and they made his son Josiah the next king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Josiah was eight years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem thirty-one years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did what was pleasing in the Lord’s sight and followed the example of his ancestor David. He did not turn away from doing what was right.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During the eighth year of his reign, while he was still young, Josiah began to seek the God of his ancestor David. Then in the twelfth year he began to purify Judah and Jerusalem, destroying all the pagan shrines, the Asherah poles, and the carved idols and cast images.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He ordered that the altars of Baal be demolished and that the incense altars which stood above them be broken down. He also made sure that the Asherah poles, the carved idols, and the cast images were smashed and scattered over the graves of those who had sacrificed to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He burned the bones of the pagan priests on their own altars, and so he purified Judah and Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did the same thing in the towns of Manasseh, Ephraim, and Simeon, even as far as Naphtali, and in the regions all around them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He destroyed the pagan altars and the Asherah poles, and he crushed the idols into dust. He cut down all the incense altars throughout the land of Israel. Finally, he returned to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the eighteenth year of his reign, after he had purified the land and the Temple, Josiah appointed Shaphan son of Azaliah, Maaseiah the governor of Jerusalem, and Joah son of Joahaz, the royal historian, to repair the Temple of the Lord his God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They gave Hilkiah the high priest the money that had been collected by the Levites who served as gatekeepers at the Temple of God. The gifts were brought by people from Manasseh, Ephraim, and from all the remnant of Israel, as well as from all Judah, Benjamin, and the people of Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He entrusted the money to the men assigned to supervise the restoration of the Lord’s Temple. Then they paid the workers who did the repairs and renovation of the Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They hired carpenters and builders, who purchased finished stone for the walls and timber for the rafters and beams. They restored what earlier kings of Judah had allowed to fall into ruin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The workers served faithfully under the leadership of Jahath and Obadiah, Levites of the Merarite clan, and Zechariah and Meshullam, Levites of the Kohathite clan. Other Levites, all of whom were skilled musicians,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: were put in charge of the laborers of the various trades. Still others assisted as secretaries, officials, and gatekeepers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While they were bringing out the money collected at the Lord’s Temple, Hilkiah the priest found the Book of the Law of the Lord that was written by Moses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hilkiah said to Shaphan the court secretary, “I have found the Book of the Law in the Lord’s Temple!” Then Hilkiah gave the scroll to Shaphan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shaphan took the scroll to the king and reported, “Your officials are doing everything they were assigned to do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The money that was collected at the Temple of the Lord has been turned over to the supervisors and workmen.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shaphan also told the king, “Hilkiah the priest has given me a scroll.” So Shaphan read it to the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the king heard what was written in the Law, he tore his clothes in despair.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he gave these orders to Hilkiah, Ahikam son of Shaphan, Acbor son of Micaiah, Shaphan the court secretary, and Asaiah the king’s personal adviser:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Go to the Temple and speak to the Lord for me and for all the remnant of Israel and Judah. Inquire about the words written in the scroll that has been found. For the Lord’s great anger has been poured out on us because our ancestors have not obeyed the word of the Lord. We have not been doing everything this scroll says we must do.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Hilkiah and the other men went to the New Quarter of Jerusalem to consult with the prophet Huldah. She was the wife of Shallum son of Tikvah, son of Harhas, the keeper of the Temple wardrobe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She said to them, “The Lord, the God of Israel, has spoken! Go back and tell the man who sent you,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘This is what the Lord says: I am going to bring disaster on this city and its people. All the curses written in the scroll that was read to the king of Judah will come true.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For my people have abandoned me and offered sacrifices to pagan gods, and I am very angry with them for everything they have done. My anger will be poured out on this place, and it will not be quenched.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But go to the king of Judah who sent you to seek the Lord and tell him: ‘This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says concerning the message you have just heard:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You were sorry and humbled yourself before God when you heard his words against this city and its people. You humbled yourself and tore your clothing in despair and wept before me in repentance. And I have indeed heard you, says the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So I will not send the promised disaster until after you have died and been buried in peace. You yourself will not see the disaster I am going to bring on this city and its people.’”
So they took her message back to the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king summoned all the elders of Judah and Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the king went up to the Temple of the Lord with all the people of Judah and Jerusalem, along with the priests and the Levites—all the people from the greatest to the least. There the king read to them the entire Book of the Covenant that had been found in the Lord’s Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king took his place of authority beside the pillar and renewed the covenant in the Lord’s presence. He pledged to obey the Lord by keeping all his commands, laws, and decrees with all his heart and soul. He promised to obey all the terms of the covenant that were written in the scroll.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And he required everyone in Jerusalem and the people of Benjamin to make a similar pledge. The people of Jerusalem did so, renewing their covenant with God, the God of their ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Josiah removed all detestable idols from the entire land of Israel and required everyone to worship the Lord their God. And throughout the rest of his lifetime, they did not turn away from the Lord, the God of their ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Josiah announced that the Passover of the Lord would be celebrated in Jerusalem, and so the Passover lamb was slaughtered on the fourteenth day of the first month.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Josiah also assigned the priests to their duties and encouraged them in their work at the Temple of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He issued this order to the Levites, who were to teach all Israel and who had been set apart to serve the Lord: “Put the holy Ark in the Temple that was built by Solomon son of David, the king of Israel. You no longer need to carry it back and forth on your shoulders. Now spend your time serving the Lord your God and his people Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Report for duty according to the family divisions of your ancestors, following the directions of King David of Israel and the directions of his son Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then stand in the sanctuary at the place appointed for your family division and help the families assigned to you as they bring their offerings to the Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Slaughter the Passover lambs, purify yourselves, and prepare to help those who come. Follow all the directions that the Lord gave through Moses.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Josiah provided 30,000 lambs and young goats for the people’s Passover offerings, along with 3,000 cattle, all from the king’s own flocks and herds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king’s officials also made willing contributions to the people, priests, and Levites. Hilkiah, Zechariah, and Jehiel, the administrators of God’s Temple, gave the priests 2,600 lambs and young goats and 300 cattle as Passover offerings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Levite leaders—Conaniah and his brothers Shemaiah and Nethanel, as well as Hashabiah, Jeiel, and Jozabad—gave 5,000 lambs and young goats and 500 cattle to the Levites for their Passover offerings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When everything was ready for the Passover celebration, the priests and the Levites took their places, organized by their divisions, as the king had commanded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Levites then slaughtered the Passover lambs and presented the blood to the priests, who sprinkled the blood on the altar while the Levites prepared the animals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They divided the burnt offerings among the people by their family groups, so they could offer them to the Lord as prescribed in the Book of Moses. They did the same with the cattle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they roasted the Passover lambs as prescribed; and they boiled the holy offerings in pots, kettles, and pans, and brought them out quickly so the people could eat them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Afterward the Levites prepared Passover offerings for themselves and for the priests—the descendants of Aaron—because the priests had been busy from morning till night offering the burnt offerings and the fat portions. The Levites took responsibility for all these preparations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The musicians, descendants of Asaph, were in their assigned places, following the commands that had been given by David, Asaph, Heman, and Jeduthun, the king’s seer. The gatekeepers guarded the gates and did not need to leave their posts of duty, for their Passover offerings were prepared for them by their fellow Levites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The entire ceremony for the Lord’s Passover was completed that day. All the burnt offerings were sacrificed on the altar of the Lord, as King Josiah had commanded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the Israelites present in Jerusalem celebrated Passover and the Festival of Unleavened Bread for seven days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Never since the time of the prophet Samuel had there been such a Passover. None of the kings of Israel had ever kept a Passover as Josiah did, involving all the priests and Levites, all the people of Jerusalem, and people from all over Judah and Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This Passover was celebrated in the eighteenth year of Josiah’s reign.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Josiah had finished restoring the Temple, King Neco of Egypt led his army up from Egypt to do battle at Carchemish on the Euphrates River, and Josiah and his army marched out to fight him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But King Neco sent messengers to Josiah with this message:
“What do you want with me, king of Judah? I have no quarrel with you today! I am on my way to fight another nation, and God has told me to hurry! Do not interfere with God, who is with me, or he will destroy you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Josiah refused to listen to Neco, to whom God had indeed spoken, and he would not turn back. Instead, he disguised himself and led his army into battle on the plain of Megiddo.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the enemy archers hit King Josiah with their arrows and wounded him. He cried out to his men, “Take me from the battle, for I am badly wounded!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they lifted Josiah out of his chariot and placed him in another chariot. Then they brought him back to Jerusalem, where he died. He was buried there in the royal cemetery. And all Judah and Jerusalem mourned for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator
